meaning: An average job schedule.
example: He decided that he was going to look for a 9-to-5 job soon.

meaning: A bad (or morally questionable) person within a group of good individuals, who might corrupt the entire group. Like a rotten apple in a barrel of good ones.
example: Onlookers were worried that the entire group of trick-or-treaters was bad, but there were really only a couple of bad apples.

meaning: Thirteen, or one more than an actual dozen (which is twelve).
example: We went to the grocery store and bought a baker's dozen of chocolate chip muffins. We're looking forward to eating them later.

meaning: An approximate figure.
example: This is only a ballpark figure. It may not be very accurate once you add up all the numbers.

idiom: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush
meaning: What you have at this moment carries more value than something you might obtain later.
example: Jane asked me whether she should take the current job offer or wait for a better one. I told her to accept the current one. After all, a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.

meaning: To a small extent or a small amount.
example: I think I'll have just a little bit of cereal this morning. I'm not very hungry

meaning: Something that seems bad initially, but that ends up having a positive outcome.
example: He was very upset about not getting the job, but it ended up being a blessing in disguise as he got a better one later on.

meaning: A reason why one is upset.
example: I have a bone to pick with you. I don't like the way you did this.

meaning: A person who is different from others in a very positive way.
example: Everyone thought that Sasha was a breath of fresh air. She was so clever and friendly, and so different from anyone else they'd ever met.

meaning: A group of people, animals, or objects.
example: A bunch of friends and I are going on a day trip tomorrow.

meaning: You have a grievance of some kind—or an attitude—that you won't let go of.
example: Have you met Max? That guy has a real chip on his shoulder. He's always a bit arrogant and on the defensive.

idiom: A day late and a dollar short
meaning: Too little and too late.
example: Elizabeth tried to hand in her assignment, but her teacher said it was a day late and a dollar short.

meaning: A very common thing or occurrence.
example: Shirts in that style are a dime a dozen at the local mall.

meaning: Something incredible, usually in a negative way.
example: That storm the other day was a real doozy! I don't think I'll ever forget it. The thunder was terrible.

meaning: Someone who has a very skeptical attitude and who requires strong evidence to believe something.
example: Jonathan is very hard to convince about anything. He always wants evidence. He's a real doubting Thomas.

meaning: Has a great many differences from something.
example: That movie was a far cry from anything I would like. I just didn't enjoy it.

meaning: Useless or unnecessary.
example: The team decided that the additional guest speaker was a fifth wheel and not necessary to include.

meaning: Something that seems promising at first but ultimately doesn't deliver anything.
example: We were excited about what happened, but it ended up just being a flash in the pan. Nothing came of it.

idiom: A fool and his money are easily parted
meaning: It's easy to convince a foolish person to give you their money for something silly.
example: I can't believe so many people have bought the product from that questionable infomercial. Well, you know what they say! A fool and his money are easily parted.

meaning: Made an excellent effort (but might not have done very well otherwise).
example: I have to give the script writers an A for effort, but I don't feel that the program came together very well in the end.

meaning: A situation in which you can choose one path or another.
example: I think I've reached a fork in the road here. I don't know which direction to go.

meaning: A person who helps others in need.
example: Shelly was always such a good Samaritan. She always helped people in need.

meaning: Something—perhaps irrational—that consistently worries you.
example: Helen tended to be difficult to deal with. She had a lot of hang-ups, and it was easy to offend her.

meaning: Someone who is difficult to get to know or understand, or someone who is tricky to deal with.
example: Yes, I'm enjoying my new job. My boss, though, is a hard nut to crack. I'm having difficulty in understanding what he wants.

meaning: An issue, probably from current events, that is causing a lot of discussion and controversy.
example: The family tried to avoid bringing up political hot potatoes during the holidays.

meaning: A bribe or other illegal payment of money, usually offered to get someone to do something.
example: The politician was known to be corrupt. It had been proven that he had accepted kickbacks from several people.

meaning: A person (possibly someone recognized by both participants in the conversation) who imparted the information in question.
example: How did I find out that your sister is getting married? A little bird told me.

idiom: A little learning is a dangerous thing
meaning: People who have only a limited understanding of something can be dangerous.
example: Some people are always promoting opinions that make me realize that a little learning can be a dangerous thing.

meaning: An inadequate memory
example: I can't believe I forgot that! I have a memory like a sieve.

meaning: Tell me your thoughts.
example: You're very quiet today. A penny for your thoughts

idiom: A penny saved is a penny earned
meaning: If you save money right now, you will have more later.
example: Try to save more of your money. Remember that a penny saved is a penny earned.

meaning: When several things go wrong at once, creating the worst situation possible.
example: The family seemed to be experiencing a perfect storm of unfortunate events.

idiom: A picture is worth a thousand words
meaning: It is more effective to show than it is to tell.
example: Look at the sad faces on everyone. They wouldn’t believe it if they hadn’t seen it. A picture is worth a thousand words

meaning: Very easy.
example: Don't worry about the exam. I took one for the same course last year and it was a piece of cake.

meaning: Someone who is always cheerful and makes other people feel more positive.
example: Audrey is a ray of sunshine. She is always so cheerful that she inevitably cheers me up as well.

meaning: Something that costs too much for what it is really worth.
example: The coat was a rip-off. It was extremely expensive and ended up being lowquality.

meaning: To be crazy.
example: We thought he had a screw loose when we saw him dancing around as if his shoes were on fire!

meaning: A mistake.
example: It turned out that what they said in the announcement was a screwup! They're not really opening on August 15th.

idiom: A sledgehammer to crack a nut
meaning: Using a disproportionate (and probably ineffective) solution for a problem.
example: I can't understand why Charles is doing such drastic things to try to solve a simple problem. It's like using a sledgehammer to crack a nut!

meaning: A clever and quick-thinking person.
example: You're a really smart cookie, so you're sure to do well on the test if you study hard.

meaning: A series of events gain momentum and build upon one another, leading to a more impactful outcome.
example: Things started to go wrong; eventually, it seemed like they were dealing with a snowball effect.

meaning: No chance of something happening.
example: Jake wants to travel this summer but there's not a snowball's chance in hell that he will get to.

idiom: A stitch in time saves nine
meaning: Deal with the problem now because it will get worse if you leave it.
example: Abby decided to deal with the problem and not leave it for later. After all, a stitch in time saves nine.

meaning: Very close by.
example: We had an awesome time on vacation! The hotel was just a stone's throw away from lots of the museums we were eager to visit.

meaning: A lot of fuss about an insignificant problem.
example: Jill and Amy got really upset about the issue but calmed down later on. They realized it was just a storm in a teacup.

meaning: There is likely to be significant trouble in the near future.
example: Do you really think everything is okay? I have a feeling that if it is, it won't be for long. I think a storm is brewing.

meaning: An approach that will definitely lead to something happening.
example: Failing to study early on in a course is a surefire way of getting a bad mark

meaning: To love sweet foods and flavors.
example: I'm afraid I have a terrible sweet tooth. I eat far too much cake and candy.

meaning: Something that is difficult to decide.
example: She couldn't decide which of her friends had improved the most in their running skills. It was a toss-up!

meaning: Gives the impression of not being aware of what is happening in the present moment.
example: He seemed a bit absentminded that day. His focus seemed to be somewhere else.

meaning: A hidden, but very effective, method for winning a conflict.
example: My resume ended up being my ace in the hole when competing for the job. I was the most highly qualified.

meaning: A hidden advantage in a competition.
example: No, I'm not worried about the upcoming competition. I have an ace up my sleeve.

meaning: A significant weakness and/or reason for potential downfall.
example: His love of junk food was his Achilles' heel. It really was his downfall, as it greatly affected his health.

meaning: An important or critical test of something.
example: Beth felt that their outing on the upcoming weekend would be the acid test for her friendship with Meredith. It would tell her whether the friendship could really continue.

meaning: In every area and/or in every way.
example: We decided to change the rules for the contest across the board. They just weren't fair.

meaning: A person's actions will give you a better idea of their character than their words.
example: My friend apologized for upsetting me, but I'm not sure if I believe that she will change yet. Actions speak louder than words.

meaning: To make something even worse.
example: Maxine tried to help with the problem, but it turned out that her advice only added fuel to the fire.

meaning: To worsen an already bad situation or cause more problems for someone.
example: I bought a new sweater that I thought was on sale, but they didn't give me the discount. To add insult to injury, they wouldn't give me a refund when I brought it back.

meaning: Running out of time.
example: Madison was really rushing with the end of her exam. She was working against the clock.

meaning: To finish something earlier than the schedule requires.
example: Things are getting done ahead of schedule. Our boss is very pleased about that.

meaning: Seems more intimidating than he, she, or it actually is.
example: Don't worry about Larry getting angry. He's a bit like his big dog. His bark is worse than his bite!

meaning: Any existing agreements are discarded.
example: When Angela found out that her friend had talked behind her back, she decided that all bets were off and she would do the same to her.

meaning: I don't understand it.
example: I'm having a hard time understanding this instructions pamphlet. It's all Greek to me.

meaning: To be very kind and loving to others. (This can sometimes be said in a sarcastic manner, in reference to a person who seems to be the opposite.)
example: Abigail is a wonderful, caring person. She's all heart.

meaning: All in the same situation.
example: We are all in the same situation right now. Without a doubt, we are all in the same boat.

meaning: I was joking before, but now I'm going to speak seriously.
example: So, do you think it would be okay if I spent all day, every day, at the beach this summer? But all kidding aside, I do want to spend a lot of time by the ocean this year

meaning: Something (for example, a conversation) that doesn't stay on target with the primary topic or purpose—it’s a bit scattered in different directions.
example: We discussed the issue, but the conversation was all over the map. It wasn't very focused.

meaning: Ready to go or proceed.
example: Are you all set to go? We need to leave soon.

meaning: Clumsy, especially with intricate tasks that require a lot of dexterity.
example: I ended up ruining my knitting project. I'm all thumbs with complicated things like that.

meaning: Wrong to the extent of being unbelievable or just silly.
example: Harry really gets on my nerves sometimes. Some of the things he says are all wet. He tends to be silly.

meaning: To be present when something is happening, without actually participating in it.
example: I thought that my friend wanted to come on the trip to keep me company and make me feel better, but it turned out that she was just along for the ride.

meaning: A sudden change, usually in the opposite direction.
example: She did an about-face on this topic a little while ago. She completely changed her position and opinions.

meaning: An encumbrance or significant burden.
example: Her illness was extremely persistent and difficult to deal with. It was like an albatross around her neck.

idiom: An apple a day keeps the doctor away
meaning: Eating healthfully, for example eating apples, will help to preserve good health.
example: My co-workers always joke about how I bring an apple for lunch every day. But I tell them that an apple a day keeps the doctor away.

idiom: An old head on young shoulders
meaning: Someone who seems to have more perception and wisdom than most other people the same age.
example: Marissa was an old head on young shoulders. She was only seventeen years old but seemed so wise and sensible.

meaning: Someone who seems to have more emotional insight and wisdom than other people the same age.
example: Everyone said that Henry was an old soul. He seemed to have so much wisdom and insight for a sixteen-year-old boy.

meaning: Someone who is extremely open about themselves.
example: It was very easy to get to know Hannah. She was an open book and made friends easily.

idiom: An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure
meaning: It's better to deal with a problem early. It will be more difficult to fix if you leave it for later.
example: Henry decided to go to the doctor about his headaches. It probably wasn't anything serious, but an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.

meaning: Are you joking? Often said to express disbelief, even if the speaker doesn't think that the other person is joking.
example: Are you kidding me? I can't believe that what you just said is true. Is it?

meaning: A person who offers opinions and advice but shows no evidence that they actually have any necessary knowledge and/or skill. Especially used with regard to American football.
example: Bob wouldn't keep quiet during the football game; he constantly talked about what the players were doing wrong. He's such an armchair quarterback.

meaning: To be heavily armed.
example: I watched that war movie I mentioned last night. All the characters were armed to the teeth.

meaning: At every time of day and night.
example: Their boss seems quite unreasonable. It appears he expects an immediate response from them around-the-clock!

meaning: Very busy
example: I'm as busy as a bee this morning. I've run lots of errands and completed lots of tasks.

meaning: Very simple and easy.
example: Don't worry about learning how to ride a bike. It's as easy as ABC once you get going.

meaning: Extremely easy.
example: No problem. I'll show you to how to do this tomorrow. Don't worry! It's as easy as pie.

idiom: As genuine as a three-dollar bill
meaning: Fake, as three-dollar bills do not exist.
example: Xavier was showing us many of his antiques, telling us that they are rare and expensive. In my opinion, though, some of them are about as genuine as a three-dollar bill.

meaning: Happy and content.
example: Don't worry about the kids. They're as happy as clams playing video games in the other room!

meaning: Very quiet and reserved.
example: She is as quiet as a mouse. It seems like she hardly ever speaks.

meaning: Extremely rare or non-existent.
example: No, I have never seen that animal even though it's supposed to live around here. I've found they're as rare as hen's teeth.

meaning: It's good or perfect.
example: Maggie asked me how my work was going and I told her the truth, that it's as right as rain.

meaning: Either in a straight line or directly, without the use of roads.
example: The mall is only two miles away, as the crow flies. It's takes longer to get there when you take certain routes.

idiom: As white as a sheet/as white as a ghost
meaning: Extremely pale, so much so that it causes concern.
example: What's wrong? You look as white as a sheet! Are you ill? Has something terrible happened?

meaning: In the best-case scenario.
example: At best, I can say that he was kind of creative in his essay. It wasn't very good, overall.

meaning: At liberty when one shouldn't be. For example, if a criminal has escaped from the authorities and his whereabouts are unknown.
example: The news bulletin said that the individual who escaped from prison is still at-large.

meaning: At a minimum.
example: It's disappointing that she can't go with you this time, but at least she might be able to next time.

meaning: In conflict with each other.
example: The two co-workers were at loggerheads on the project. They just couldn't agree on the correct direction.

meaning: Getting extremely frustrated and close to becoming angry.
example: Janette explained that she was at her wits' end with a few of her friends. They were very difficult to deal with and she felt she couldn't communicate with them.

idiom: At the bottom of the totem pole
meaning: Having a low-status position, especially at work.
example: Michael decided against giving any suggestions about how things should be done at work. After all, he was still at the bottom of the totem pole and didn't have much influence.

meaning: Extremely early in the morning.
example: They need to wake up at what seems like the crack of dawn in order to get there in time.

idiom: At the drop of a hat
meaning: Right away and without hesitation.
example: Juliana was really impatient as she waited for her friends to join her, but they couldn't just come over at the drop of a hat.

idiom: At the end of your rope
meaning: Reached the limit of endurance and/or patience with something or someone.
example: The teacher felt like she was almost at the end of her rope with some of the students. They were very difficult to deal with in class and liked to test her patience.

meaning: Someone born during the years following World War II.
example: Linda was born a few years after WWII, so she is part of the baby boomer generation. She's always talking about how she's a baby boomer.

meaning: A passenger who tries to interfere with the driver's driving.
example: Tammy always gets very irritated with backseat drivers. She can't understand why they won't just trust her to drive well!

meaning: To go back to thinking about the basic elements of something.
example: This issue seems to have become quite complex. Let's just try to go back to basics, so that we can better understand it.

meaning: Back to the beginning of an endeavor.
example: Everything has gone wrong with the project! We have to go back to square one.

meaning: After experiencing failure, it's time to start a task over from scratch.
example: Ashley and her co-workers realized their first attempt at the task had been unsuccessful and they needed to go back to the drawing board.

meaning: A compliment that is really meant as an insult.
example: Can you believe how rude she was? She gave me such a backhanded compliment. She said that it's hard to be as beautiful as she is, and she would rather just be sweetly pretty like I am. She was definitely implying that I'm not as attractive as she is.

meaning: Ill or negative feelings.
example: There is quite a bit of bad blood between them now. They used to be friends, but a lot has happened to cause anger between them.

meaning: Hair is not looking as good as one would like
example: Zack said he was having a very bad hair day. It was sticking up all over the place and he couldn't seem to tame it!

meaning: Trying to deal with a serious situation in a negligent way.
example: Linda was amazed at the bad advice her cousin gave her on how to deal with the serious problem she was experiencing. It would be like putting a Band-Aid on a bullet wound.

meaning: To be searching for solutions in the wrong places.
example: I'm afraid you're barking up the wrong tree. I can't help you with your problem.

meaning: To accomplish a task perfectly. A term taken from baseball.
example: Melissa knew that she was batting a thousand when she wrote the quiz. She knew the answer to every question.

meaning: Go ahead.
example: I tried to get him to agree but wasn't successful. If you want to make an attempt, be my guest.

meaning: Remember something, especially while thinking about something else.
example: It's true that we lost the game, but keep in mind that the other team cheated.

meaning: To leave really quickly, especially to flee a difficult situation.
example: Ethan and Michael jumped out of their seats when they realized how tricky the situation had become. They beat a hasty retreat.

meaning: Trying to avoid saying something directly, often because the truth is uncomfortable.
example: Don't beat around the bush! Just tell me what you want to say.

meaning: You do something before someone else manages to.
example: Joshua was determined to practice hard and beat his brother to the draw when it came to getting on a baseball team.

meaning: To accomplish something before someone else does.
example: I'm so frustrated! I thought I was the first one to think of this idea, but it turned out that Mason beat me to the punch!

meaning: To search thoroughly.
example: She said she simply can't find her tablet. She claimed that she beat the bushes looking for it and there's just no sign of it.

meaning: Continuing to talk about a subject that is now useless to discuss.
example: Matthew kept talking about the subject and nobody knew why. Beating a dead horse like that was pointless.

meaning: Trying to avoid a topic.
example: No more beating around the bush! Tell me exactly what I need to know.

meaning: Hair that is messy after sleeping on it.
example: I had really bad bed head this morning. My hair was sticking up all over the place when I got up to brush my teeth!

meaning: A blissfully happy and comfortable situation.
example: It's a good job, but don't expect it to be a bed of roses. It's quite difficult in many ways.

meaning: Very soon.
example: The town is only about fifteen minutes away by car. We'll be there before you know it.

meaning: Without someone knowing.
example: Max went behind my back and told people my secret. I'm really upset and don't know if we can be friends anymore.

meaning: In a difficult position or unfavorable circumstances.
example: I feel like I'm behind the eight ball here. These are really tricky circumstances.

meaning: Exercising caution and avoiding of risks.
example: Brian is a very cautious person. He avoids risks whenever possible. Belts and suspenders is his motto.

meaning: Try extremely hard to do something, usually to help someone with a specific issue.
example: They bent over backward to help me learn this. I will always appreciate the effort they made.

meaning: Annoyed and upset.
example: There's no need to get so bent out of shape! I didn't say anything that you should be very angry about.

meaning: Very troubled or anxious and distraught.
example: Alexander was beside himself. He was so incredibly upset about his uncle's illness. His uncle had always been like a father to him.

meaning: Irrelevant.
example: They dismissed what I said, claiming that it was beside the point. They had already concluded the discussion.

meaning: Best friend.
example: We're really good friends. She's my bestie, actually.

meaning: To risk everything on an endeavor that you believe will be successful.
example: I tried to convince David to think more carefully about what he was doing. It's very dangerous to bet the ranch in that way. He could lose everything.

meaning: It's preferable to do a thing late than to never do it.
example: It took me a long time to get there, but better late than never!

idiom: Between a rock and a hard place
meaning: Having to choose between two inadequate options when in a difficult situation.
example: Sean's friends can't understand why he hasn't been able to make a decision yet, but when you look at his options his hesitation is clear. Neither of them are good; he's between a rock and a hard place.

idiom: Between the devil and the deep blue sea
meaning: Having to deal with the reality of two difficult possible outcomes for the same situation.
example: I think we're between the devil and the deep blue sea in this situation. No matter what we do, it's not going to solve the problem!

meaning: Outside of the limits of socially or morally acceptable behavior.
example: The way they acted was truly beyond the pale. It was simply unacceptable. Don't you agree?

meaning: A very important person, especially the most important person in an organization.
example: The boss is the big cheese in our company. She's the person who decides what gets done.

idiom: Big fish in a small pond
meaning: Someone who seems more significant than they are because they live in a small or relatively insignificant community.
example: Mr. Jones is always so arrogant at social events. He and his family are important in their little town. They're big fish in a small pond.

meaning: A powerful person. Often used in a sarcastic or resentful way.
example: Marvin thinks he's a big shot. He thinks he's better than us and can tell us what to do

meaning: An influential, powerful, and important person.
example: He's a big wheel in this organization. Whatever he says goes.

meaning: More value for money.
example: The salesperson directed me to a fridge different from the one I had originally wanted to buy. He claimed that it offered better features and bigger bang for my buck.

meaning: A powerful person with a high position in a corporate structure.
example: Everyone knows that the CEO is the most important bigwig in any company.

meaning: A broad and expansive view of a place or something.
example: The helicopter ride was a lot of fun! We got a bird's-eye view of the entire town!

idiom: Birds of a feather flock together
meaning: Friends are often alike (usually used in a negative sense).
example: They weren't surprised that the group of friends exhibited similar personalities. After all, birds of a feather flock together.

idiom: Bite off more than you can chew
meaning: To take on a task that you're unable to finish.
example: We weren't surprised when Barbara and Matthew couldn't finish the task. They'd bitten off more than they could chew.

meaning: To commence with something that is unpleasant, but inevitable.
example: They decided to bite the bullet and go ahead with the necessary expense.

meaning: For something to cease to exist.
example: My plans for vacation bit the dust when I found out that I'd only be getting one week off.

meaning: To stop talking.
example: I was going to give my opinion on his outfit, but I decided to bite my tongue at the last minute. I didn't think he'd like what I had to say.

meaning: To be bruised.
example: Christopher's knees were black and blue after falling off his bike a few days ago.

meaning: To think in an extreme way—everything is either completely right or entirely wrong.
example: Josh always seemed to take a black-and-white view of things. It was difficult to make him see that there could be gray areas.

meaning: An illegal market of some sort.
example: The counterfeit goods market is illegal. It is a black market.

meaning: To not fit in within a specific group.
example: When she was growing up, Julia felt like she was the black sheep of her family. She was very rebellious and didn't feel like she fit in.

meaning: A very formal event in which men must wear tuxedos and women wear formal gowns.
example: The banquet was a black tie event. That's why everyone wore tuxedos and gowns.

meaning: To cause someone to be rejected by workplaces or other establishments throughout a field in a certain location.
example: The actor realized that he'd been blackballed since he hadn't been able to get along with a certain director. He couldn’t get any new parts.

meaning: A vivid reminder of the past.
example: Did you see the old acid-washed jean jacket that Megan found in her closet yesterday? Talk about a blast from the past! I think I had one of those.

meaning: To take a different and challenging path.
example: Emily was so daring and adventurous. She wasn't afraid of making unconventional choices and blazing a trail.

meaning: Incredibly impressed me.
example: Yes, we went to the movie last night. It really blew me away! I thought it was incredible.

meaning: An extremely beautiful and glamorous woman with blonde (probably light blonde) hair
example: Many of the actresses of the 1940s and ’50s were called blonde bombshells. Marilyn Monroe is certainly the most famous.

meaning: To lose one's temper.
example: My friend blew a fuse the other day when I found fault with their work. I guess I don't really blame them for getting angry.

meaning: To vent energy, frustration, or anger.
example: I have had a very stressful week and I'm hoping to blow off some steam this Saturday. I'll be playing baseball with my team.

meaning: To lose one's temper.
example: They were afraid that she would blow her top when she heard the news. It was just the kind of thing that could make her angry.

meaning: Exaggerating and/or making false claims about oneself, most often to make oneself look better.
example: Richard was known for boasting about his accomplishments. People thought he was just blowing smoke.

meaning: To be a member of the aristocracy or a royal family. In the American context, this can apply to people who belong to old and famous families with a great deal of wealth.
example: The family considered themselves blue blood, but I didn't think they were as distinguished as they thought.

meaning: A law meant to regulate personal behavior (for example, gambling or seeing a certain movie).
example: I didn't realize that this state had any blue laws. Not being allowed to gamble is unusual.

meaning: The point at which someone becomes angry.
example: I think I'm starting to reach my boiling point! They're making me so mad!

meaning: Something that occurs without any warning and is a total surprise.
example: Hearing the news caught us off guard. It was really a bolt from the blue.

meaning: A source of conflict or disagreement.
example: The major bone of contention was the question of whether or not Jonah and James should be in charge of the project. No one could agree and people were debating each man's merits.

meaning: Someone who reads books very frequently, or almost all of the time.
example: I'm definitely a bookworm. I love to read and do so whenever I get the chance

idiom: Born with a silver spoon in one's mouth
meaning: To be born into a wealthy family with lots of privileges.
example: Zoe always had lots of designer clothes and expensive jewelry when she was a kid. She was born with a silver spoon in her mouth.

meaning: The lowest quality option.
example: Wow! They were really scraping the bottom of the barrel with this. They're using their last option.

meaning: To feel trapped in some way.
example: James felt boxed in with the situation. He didn't feel he had any real options.

meaning: To come up with as many ideas as possible.
example: The team at the office brainstormed to come up with ideas for the new venture

meaning: A job or endeavor that allows someone to make a living.
example: Abigail does several different kinds of work, but tutoring is her bread and butter.

meaning: A wish of good luck, especially in a performance.
example: You're starring in a play tonight? That's amazing! Well, break a leg!

meaning: To neither gain nor lose money.
example: Patrick is worried about his investment, thinking it might have been unwise. He'd be happy and relieved just to break even.

meaning: To romantically disappoint someone who is in love with you.
example: He was afraid of telling her his real feelings in case he broke her heart.

meaning: For something to cost a huge amount of money.
example: I'm glad to hear about our upcoming vacation to Hawaii. Aren't you worried that it might break the bank, though?

meaning: Do something to help new acquaintances feel more comfortable
example: Things were awkward at the party until we played a game to help break the ice.

meaning: To tell someone (or a group of people) news about something.
example: It took her a while to get up the courage to break the news about what had happened.

meaning: To get through something with very little or no effort.
example: Abby breezed through the course. She found it very easy and it didn't take a great deal of effort.

meaning: Early in the morning.
example: Remember to wake up bright and early tomorrow. There's a lot to do.

meaning: To be extremely successful, usually in a performance
example: The cast brought down the house with last night's performance. They were amazing and got a standing ovation!

meaning: To earn most, or all, of the money an individual or family needs.
example: Her best friend told her there's no shame in any honest job, as long as it lets you bring home the bacon.

meaning: To make my best effort.
example: I promised my friends that I'd bring my A game to the competition tomorrow, so I need to get lots of sleep.

meaning: To begin speaking on a topic.
example: He brought up a topic I didn't want to discuss. I explained that I just didn't want to have a conversation about that today.

meaning: To earn Brownie points is to be good and kind to others. Brownie refers to the Brownies, a club for kids.
example: Kate is always kind and helpful to everyone. And she's so honest, too. She's always earning her Brownie points!

meaning: To be clumsy and perhaps oafish when a more delicate approach is needed.
example: Walt didn't know how to act in a delicate situation. He was like a bull in a china shop.

meaning: Hamburgers and hotdogs (a hotdog is a sausage made of a meat such as pork or beef in a bread bun).
example: Come to my picnic next week! We're having some burgers and dogs.

meaning: To ruin relationships.
example: Paul was considered very unreliable by everyone. He was known for burning bridges and ruining friendships.

idiom: Burn the candle at both ends
meaning: To live a frantic sort of life, going to bed too late and having to wake up too early, thus not getting enough rest.
example: I'm worried about Tim. I think he's burning the candle at both ends. He doesn't get enough rest and always seems worried and frantic.

meaning: To continue working late into the night. This is a reference to long ago when people didn't have electric light.
example: Evan and Elsie are still working on their school assignment and it's well past three o'clock in the morning. They're really burning the midnight oil!

meaning: To feel exhausted as the result of a specific endeavor.
example: William felt burned out from his job. He was too tired to think and felt like he couldn't deal with anything else.

meaning: To let go of a disagreement or grudge and call a truce.
example: They have been friends for a long time. When they fought a few weeks ago, they ended up not talking for several days. They eventually decided to make up and bury the hatchet, though.

idiom: Bury your head in the sand
meaning: Pretending something doesn't exist, or completely ignoring it.
example: I know you're having a difficult time with the situation but burying your head in the sand isn't going to help make the problem go away.

meaning: Someone who always seems to be busy.
example: Louise is definitely a busy bee. She's always running around, getting things done.

meaning: To flatter and be excessively nice to someone, in an attempt to make them see things your way or do something you want.
example: His parents still haven't said that he's allowed to go. He's still trying to butter them up.

meaning: To stop talking and be quiet.
example: The teacher told her pupil to button his lip while she was talking. He was trying to interrupt her.

meaning: To buy a car that ends up being highly faulty or nonfunctioning.
example: He was so excited to buy his second-hand car, but it ended up being a lemon! He's going to have to spend a fortune on repairs and even then it still might give him trouble.

meaning: To buy something for very little money.
example: Do you like my new coat? I got it for a song! It was on sale.

meaning: No matter what, or by any means.
example: Don't worry about it. By hook or by crook, we’ll definitely find a way to get the job done.

meaning: Strictly following the rules.
example: They always do everything by the book. They follow the rules meticulously.

idiom: By the skin of my teeth
meaning: Barely.
example: Yes, I made it to the appointment by the skin of my teeth. I got there just five minutes before the scheduled time.

meaning: People telling something to one another verbally.
example: The business didn't really do much advertising. People learned about the line by word of mouth.

meaning: Identifying what something, or someone, really is.
example: Abby thought we were rude for calling her a liar, but I always like to call a spade a spade. She lies all the time, so she's a liar.

meaning: Decide to stop working on something for the time being.
example: I think we have accomplished as much as we can for today. Let's call it a day and continue tomorrow.

meaning: To make decisions, especially for other people.
example: The boss was the person who called the shots in the office. She made all the decisions.

meaning: To try to force someone to show that they are lying.
example: Amy told us that if we didn't accompany her this time, she would never go again. We decided to call her bluff and told her that it was fine; we didn't think she should go again anyway.

meaning: It may be calm right now but something bad is coming.
example: Everything seems okay right now, but everyone is scared that it might be the calm before the storm.

meaning: To help make someone calm.
example: Annie tried to calm her friend down after she found out some extremely upsetting news.

idiom: Can't hold a candle to something or someone
meaning: Cannot compete.
example: We felt that the movie we saw last night couldn't hold a candle to any of the films that came out last year. The script and the acting were both average.

idiom: Can't judge a book by its cover
meaning: You shouldn't attempt to judge someone or something just by how it looks.
example: Maureen said she didn't like how the new teacher looked, but I told her she shouldn't judge a book by its cover.

meaning: Cannot stay at the same level of achievement.
example: I'm afraid I just can't keep up in this advanced chemistry program. Everyone seems to have much more of a science background.

idiom: Can't put a face to the name
meaning: When you hear a name you recognize but you cannot remember what the person looks like.
example: Tom Watson? Yes, I've heard his name but can't remember what he looks like. I just can't put a face to the name.

idiom: Can't see the forest for the trees
meaning: Unable to fully see or understand the whole situation because one is distracted or overwhelmed by the details.
example: Cindy ended up making the wrong decision because she wasn't thinking clearly. She just couldn't see the forest for the trees.

meaning: Someone who makes money from cheating at cards.
example: He lost quite a bit of money at the poker game. It took a while for him to realize that he had been playing with a card shark.

meaning: To take on greater responsibility in order to help ensure a project continues.
example: Ariana decided to carry the ball on the project. She could see that her teammates weren't going to do what they should, but she wanted the endeavor to succeed. For this reason, she did most of the work.

meaning: A stomach that never seems to get upset, regardless of what one eats.
example: Don't worry about my friends getting ill from this spicy food. They have cast-iron stomachs.

meaning: To display fine attributes to people incapable of appreciating them.
example: At first, Ava was frustrated by how people weren't appreciating her work. But then she remembered what her mother had told her about casting pearls before swine.

meaning: A hope or daydream for the future that will probably never come true.
example: I'm sure that my dream of spending a month in Europe is a castle in the sky, but I guess you never know.

meaning: Why aren't you responding or talking?
example: Cat got your tongue? You haven't answered my question.

meaning: A brief nap.
example: I went for a long run this morning and I'm tired. I think I'll take a cat nap this afternoon.

meaning: Something that illogically gets in the way of something else, creating a trap. Comes from the title of the novel, Catch-22.
example: I needed to get a piece of equipment to repair something in my house. Then I found out that the equipment I needed had to be repaired before I could get it. Talk about a catch-22!

meaning: To sit in the sunshine in order to get a tan.
example: Barry enjoyed catching some rays a few days a week during the summer. He liked having a tan.

meaning: To sleep.
example: Lizzie decided to catch some Zs before starting the work she would have to do later that day.

meaning: To attract someone's interest, usually in a romantic way.
example: Olivia caught his eye the first time he saw her. She was very beautiful.

meaning: To get on a bus after going to or waiting at a stop.
example: She said she was planning to catch the bus and go to the mall today

meaning: Doing the work necessary to get where you need to be in a schedule.
example: Lots of people were on vacation last week. They are all playing catch-up in the office now.

meaning: Caught in the act of doing something one shouldn't, such as stealing.
example: The thief was caught red-handed. We actually saw him with the product in his hands.

meaning: To catch someone in the act of doing something that they shouldn't be doing.
example: The thieves were caught red-handed the other day. People saw them stealing the items and said something.

idiom: Caught with your hand in the cookie jar
meaning: Caught doing something one shouldn't be doing.
example: It looks like Mark is in trouble. He was caught with his hand in the cookie jar at work, so to speak. He stole money.

meaning: To alter plans or to start following a different leader in the middle of an event or action of some sort.
example: I was surprised when they suggested that we change plans. It seemed like changing horses in midstream. Why make huge changes right in the middle of an endeavor like that?

meaning: Significant change in feelings.
example: They both had a change of heart about their argument. They realized that their friendship was more important than politics

meaning: A cramp or stiff leg.
example: Billy had to stop running because of a terrible charley horse.

meaning: A life that seems extraordinarily lucky and strangely free of unpleasant consequences.
example: Elizabeth seemed to live a charmed life. No matter how many stupid things she did, everything always seemed to turn out okay.

meaning: Trying to pursue unrealistic dreams.
example: Monica thinks that she will become a famous actress one day, but I think she's just chasing rainbows.

meaning: A questionable past with many questionable actions, especially frowned upon or criminal activities.
example: Maxwell had a checkered past. It seemed that he had a criminal record and there were many strange rumors about him.

meaning: To feel happier when you're sad.
example: Cheer up! You look so sad. What's wrong?

meaning: To scold someone.
example: Jane was angry with her friend for betraying her. She definitely chewed her out.

meaning: To thoroughly think or talk about something.
example: I spent a long time chewing it over before I made a final decision. I always think things through like that.

meaning: Talking about something, usually just chatting.
example: The two best friends enjoyed chewing the fat as much as they could. They loved nothing more than an afternoon of good conversation.

meaning: Eat heartily.
example: This pizza looks delicious. Let's chow down!

meaning: Very pleased or happy.
example: I was chuffed to bits about my birthday presents! They were all so nice.

meaning: A fresh beginning.
example: Wouldn't it be nice to start over again with a clean slate? I'd love to be free of regrets and worries

meaning: To steal or take all of a person's possessions and/or money.
example: The property was recently robbed. The thieves completely cleaned the owners out of all their money and equipment.

meaning: Not clear at all and therefore difficult to understand.
example: I really wanted to play the new board game, but I found the instructions to be as clear as mud. It was really confusing.

meaning: To resolve a disagreement or address and resolve a resentment.
example: We decided to clear the air with Maria. We knew that she resented some of the things that we had done and so we talked to her and apologized.

meaning: To feel restless.
example: They felt closed in that winter. It was really cold outside, and they were climbing the walls, wishing it was spring and that they could go outside and play some sports.

meaning: Closely approaching success or the right answer, but not quite there.
example: During the quiz show, Joseph gave his answer to the first question, certain he had it right. But he was wrong, so the host said "close but no cigar."

meaning: Just managing to escape.
example: We managed to free ourselves from the situation but it was a close shave. We almost weren't able to.

meaning: To be unable or unwilling to listen to and think about new ideas or perspectives.
example: I didn't like William. I found him very closed-minded. He refused to listen to any ideas that contradicted anything he already thought.

meaning: To joke around, telling jokes and being silly.
example: The teacher got frustrated with her students. They wouldn't stop clowning around and they refused to concentrate on the work at hand.

meaning: An implausible or far-fetched story.
example: Yes, Corey told me about his adventures in Europe. I think it's a cock-andbull story.

meaning: To come up with a new way of saying something (a word or phrase) .
example: Meredith is quite creative. She actually coined a new term yesterday. I joked that maybe it should be added to the dictionary!

meaning: To invent a new phrase or way of expressing something.
example: I ended up coining a new phrase yesterday. People said they'd never heard something described that way before.

idiom: Cold enough to freeze the ball off a brass monkey
meaning: Very cold.
example: I was so cold yesterday, even with a heavy coat on. It was cold enough to freeze the balls off a brass monkey.

meaning: To feel nervous to the point of thinking about removing yourself from a situation
example: Ethan had cold feet about the speech. Even though he had practiced it, he got so nervous beforehand that he felt like running away.

meaning: To be cold and unfriendly to someone.
example: Mia gave me the cold shoulder the other day; she acted as if she barely knew me.

meaning: Not being used.
example: The vase had been collecting dust on that table for many years. They just never used it.

meaning: To progress in some area in life.
example: I feel that I've come a long way from how I was a few years ago. I'm much more successful now.

meaning: To gain animation in some way.
example: All of the ideas in the book came alive when I saw the documentary.

meaning: To tell the truth about something that one has done wrong.
example: The police officer advised the person she arrested to come clean with what he had done. It was better to just tell the truth, she said.

meaning: To show symptoms of a cold.
example: I came down with a cold after going for a long hike in intemperate weather.

meaning: No matter what.
example: We're going to Mexico this year, come hell or high water. Nothing will stop us!

meaning: To end up being useful.
example: That tool ended up coming in handy after I’d had it for a while.

meaning: To stop being so shy.
example: We all hoped that Helen would come out of her shell soon. She was shy and got so nervous around new people.

idiom: Come out smelling like roses/a rose
meaning: To come out seeming like a wonderful person, especially when it's not fair.
example: We were all very frustrated. Even though Patricia had done all sorts of bad things, she always came out smelling like a rose. People thought she was wonderful.

meaning: Something will be accomplished no matter what.
example: Ryan said that he would definitely get the job done, come rain or shine.

meaning: Food that comforts you and makes you feel better.
example: What is your favorite comfort food? I think mine is macaroni and cheese, or maybe hot chicken soup.

meaning: Comparing two entirely different things that really should not, or cannot, be compared.
example: Mary asked Veronica which pair of pants she liked best, but Veronica said that the styles were so different that it would be like comparing apples to oranges.

meaning: Computer is no longer working.
example: Darryl's computer crashed yesterday. He's in a panic, trying to figure out what to do to fix it.

meaning: To ruin their plans.
example: It turned out that their goose was cooked. Their plan was ruined

meaning: To plan or invent.
example: They were highly skilled at cooking up new ideas that the boss loved. We wished that we could be that inventive.

meaning: To do bookkeeping or accounting in a dishonest way, often to avoid taxes.
example: The company was a shady one. Lots of people said that they cooked the books.

meaning: Calm and relaxed.
example: Jim never gets worried about interviews. He always seems to be cool as a cucumber.

meaning: Calm down.
example: There's no need to get so angry about this! Cool your jets.

meaning: Someone who copies something someone else has done.
example: One of the kids in class said that the boy beside him was a copycat because he copied some of his math homework.

meaning: It cost me a lot of money.
example: The luxury car cost him a mint! It was extremely expensive.

idiom: Costs an arm and a leg
meaning: Costs a lot of money.
example: They were thinking about buying a boat but decided not to. The problem was that it cost an arm and a leg.

meaning: Someone who spends a lot of time on the couch in front of the TV.
example: They are worried about their cousin's health because he is such a couch potato. He doesn't get enough exercise.

meaning: Expresses complete lack of interest in something.
example: Honestly, I couldn't care less about not being invited to the party. It just doesn't matter to me.

meaning: A long distance.
example: It turned out we had to walk a country mile to get to Annie's house. It took forever.

meaning: Get a lot of things done, in a variety of areas.
example: We expect to cover a lot of ground during our meeting today. There are lots of things that we need to discuss.

meaning: To open a book and read it
example: Why are you so surprised that you don't know very much about anything? You need to crack a book sometimes.

meaning: Open a cold can of beer.
example: After a long day at work, they decided to crack open a cold one and sit outside on the porch for a while.

meaning: Make someone laugh.
example: I love that comedian. She always cracks me up!

meaning: To write a paper (or essay) in a mechanical sort of way, probably in a rush.
example: The students cranked out the paper that was due the next day

meaning: The best.
example: These students were the cream of the crop in their class. They had extremely impressive grades.

meaning: Complete silence or lack of communication about something.
example: I called Sarah the other day and left a message asking if she'd like to come over for dinner. The response: crickets!

meaning: Fake tears.
example: Noah started to cry about the situation, but we knew it was just crocodile tears.

idiom: Cross that bridge when you come to it
meaning: Deal with the problem when it becomes an obstacle.
example: Isabella tended to be a worrier, letting things overwhelm her mind. There was one potential problem that was making her very anxious. Her best friend told her to cross that bridge when she came to it.

meaning: Hope that my wish comes true.
example: I'm hoping I'll win that prize in the raffle. Cross your fingers for me.

meaning: A time when things need to finally get done.
example: It's crunch time at work. We've got lots of deadlines coming up and there's lots of work to do

meaning: Cup of coffee.
example: Adam always started his day with a cup of Joe. He didn't think he could function without coffee!

meaning: It can be dangerous to be too curious and ask too many questions.
example: If I were you, I wouldn't ask any more questions. Remember: curiosity killed the cat.

meaning: Something that is deceptive or confusing.
example: His boss threw him a real curve ball the other day. He wanted him to restart the entire project.

meaning: Unequivocal or clear, or perhaps routine.
example: The instructions were cut and dried—they left no room for questions.

idiom: Cut someone off at the knees
meaning: To humiliate someone or compel them to do something you want.
example: Daniel felt his supervisor was cutting him off at the knees by the way he was criticizing his work.

meaning: Do something well or up to standard.
example: Chloe tried her best in completing the task, but people said that she just didn't cut the mustard.

meaning: Refrain from being too critical of someone.
example: He did poorly on the test but studied hard. Cut him some slack!

meaning: Get to the point quickly.
example: We only have about fifteen minutes for this meeting, so I'm going to have to cut to the chase.

meaning: To deeply wound or hurt someone.
example: Amy felt cut to the quick when her friends rejected her. She cried for a long time afterward.

meaning: Endearing and sweet.
example: We saw the puppy their family is getting. It is as cute as a bug!

meaning: Doing a task inadequately in an effort to save money or time.
example: It seemed like the builders had cut corners and that was the reason why the building was unstable.

meaning: To criticize someone in a way that seems to be praise but actually communicates disapproval or condemnation.
example: Emma tried to give the impression to others that she was complimenting me, but I knew that she was just damning me with faint praise.

meaning: A previously unknown person who becomes prominent or known for something.
example: Did you realize that Hailey had so many talents? She's certainly a dark horse!

meaning: To suddenly realize or recognize something.
example: I was taking a walk when it suddenly dawned on me that I should do that more often. It would be good for my health.

meaning: Unintelligent or stupid.
example: That guy seems really stupid. I think he's dead from the neck up.

meaning: No longer effective.
example: The project is dead in the water. It is ruined and there is no way to move forward with it.

meaning: Extremely quiet.
example: It was dead quiet in there. But that's appropriate, of course. It's a library!

meaning: To look exactly like someone else.
example: Ashley is a dead ringer for my favorite actress. She really looks just like her.

meaning: Extremely tired.
example: They were dead tired after an exhausting day spent moving to a different city.

meaning: In a deep sleep.
example: I couldn't wake Aiden up! He was dead to the world. I think it’s because he couldn’t get any sleep on the plane.

meaning: A job that doesn't seem to have any opportunities for advancement.
example: I think that's a dead-end job. It has really low pay and there doesn't seem any way to advance.

meaning: How you really feel inside, even if you don't realize it.
example: Deep down, I think I always felt that their friendship wouldn't last.

meaning: Someone, or something, that may not seem wonderful right now but has a lot of potential.
example: Marie didn't seem very impressive at first, but her instructors realized that she was a diamond in the rough and would be a great dancer after more training.

meaning: Different people do things differently, in ways that suit their personalities.
example: I was really surprised to see how Mia decorated her house. Oh well, different strokes for different folks.

meaning: To retain your position on something in spite of what others say.
example: I don't agree with what the others are saying about this. They're right when they accuse me of digging in my heels.

meaning: Extremely cheap.
example: They went shopping the other day and found some good items for dirt cheap. There were big sales going on.

meaning: Reveal an embarrassing or scandalous secret, probably about someone else; spread gossip.
example: The tabloid dished the dirt on all sorts of celebrities. No one was sure if the stories were true, though.

meaning: To divide the rewards resulting from an endeavor.
example: The business partners divided the spoils from their newest venture.

meaning: To do no matter what the obstacles.
example: Renee decided that it was do or die with advancing in her career. She would do it, no matter what it took.

meaning: To do something kind for someone.
example: She did me a good turn yesterday. She helped me out of a tricky situation, even though she must know that there's very little I'm able to do for her in return.

idiom: Do something at the drop of a hat
meaning: To do something right away, without any planning.
example: My friends surprised me when they expected me to do something at the drop of a hat. I already had plans, so I couldn't accommodate them.

idiom: Do something by the seat of your pants
meaning: To tackle something without really knowing what you're doing at first.
example: I didn't really understand the job when I first started. I was doing it by the seat of my pants.

meaning: Isn't credible and cannot withstand scrutiny.
example: This argument doesn't hold water. It doesn't make sense and no informed person would agree with it.

meaning: Knows very little, or nothing, on a subject.
example: Jordan doesn't know beans about this. I don't know why he's offering an opinion.

meaning: A presentation of some kind that has quite a bit of style but lacks real content.
example: The speech was well-attended but it was really just a dog and pony show. Nothing important was said.

meaning: The hottest summer days.
example: I always hate the dog days of summer. It's so hard to stay cool on those extremely hot days!

meaning: A ruthless environment.
example: The corporate world can be dog-eat-dog. People often try to take advantage of you.

meaning: A certainty, or a sure bet.
example: I'm certain that my team will win the game. Dollars for doughnuts.

meaning: Don't spend time worrying about insignificant issues and small problems.
example: Stop worrying about all those little things! Remember, don't sweat the small stuff.

meaning: Food is cooked perfectly.
example: The chicken was delicious. It was truly done to a turn.

meaning: The subject is over and it's time to move on.
example: Look, there's no point in discussing this anymore. Don't beat a dead horse.

idiom: Don't count your chickens before they hatch
meaning: Don't assume that something good will happen until it has actually happened.
example: You don't know that you will be offered the job yet. Don't count your chickens before they've hatched.

meaning: There is no point in complaining or lamenting something that cannot be fixed.
example: Don't cry over spilt milk. There's nothing you can do about your dropping the ball during the game today. Just try harder next time.

idiom: Don't do anything I wouldn't do
meaning: Don't behave foolishly; sometimes said in a jovial way.
example: Have a great time in California! Don't do anything I wouldn't do.

idiom: Don't give up your day job
meaning: You're not very competent at a task, or you're not good enough to do it professionally.
example: Thanks for inviting me to your show, but I have to be honest: Don't give up your day job.

meaning: Don't be hopeful or imagine that something will happen.
example: Don't hold your breath about the vacation. There's a strong chance that it won't happen.

meaning: Don't know a person.
example: He said that I know him? That's strange. I don't know him from Adam.

idiom: Don't know if I'm coming or going
meaning: Extremely confused about a situation.
example: Honestly, I'm so confused that I don't know if I'm coming or going right now.

idiom: Don't look a gift horse in the mouth
meaning: Don't find fault with a gift you are given.
example: I always remember to never look a gift horse in the mouth. That's why I never look for fault with presents that I am given.

idiom: Don't put all your eggs in one basket
meaning: Don't make everything depend on one circumstance; avoid taking unnecessary risks.
example: You've sent out one resume, but that's not enough. Remember not to put all your eggs in one basket.

meaning: This might be the answer, but I’m not 100 percent sure.
example: It sounds like you might be allergic to dust. But don’t quote me on that, I’m not a doctor.

idiom: Don't throw the baby out with the bath water
meaning: Don't try to throw away everything in a situation when there might be elements that you would like to keep or that would benefit you to keep.
example: I think you should slow down and ensure you're making the right decision here. Remember, don't throw the baby out with the bath water.

meaning: You don't like what is being said and would rather not hear it, even though you acknowledge it could be real, or is, real.
example: Please don't talk about that. I just don't want to hear about it.

meaning: To talk or dwell on something depressing or gloomy.
example: Alfred always seemed to have a negative outlook on life. Everything was always doom and gloom.

meaning: To have to deal with two difficult things at the same time.
example: To find out that two things went wrong yesterday was a double whammy for me.

meaning: Down and depressed.
example: He's been down in the dumps lately. He just feels depressed and a bit despondent.

meaning: Sad.
example: She's down in the mouth. She’s really upset about the things that have happened lately.

meaning: For something to go wrong, especially if something goes wrong with an exciting plan.
example: We were so excited about our upcoming party plans, but everything ended up going down the tube.

meaning: To be practical and have lots of common sense.
example: One of the things I like most about Katie is how down-to-earth she is. She's always so sensible and I like going to her for advice.

meaning: The deadline for a project is quickly approaching.
example: We're down to the wire on this project! We must devote all our energy to it until it is complete.

meaning: Putting off doing something.
example: Why are you dragging your feet on dealing with this problem? The longer you leave it, the worse it might get.

idiom: Drastic times call for drastic measures
meaning: Difficult circumstances can call for decisive action.
example: Marianne felt a bit hesitant at first, but the circumstances were so serious that she knew she had to. Drastic times call for drastic measures.

meaning: To realize you have forgotten something you now want or need to remember.
example: I tried to remember what I wanted to say but drew a blank. I couldn't remember! It was quite embarrassing.

meaning: A famous individual whose presence draws people to an event.
example: The committee was excited to hear that the celebrity had agreed to appear at their event. She would definitely be a drawing card. Attendance was sure to be great!

meaning: Dressed in a very impressive way.
example: They were dressed to kill at the event. Everyone was so fashionable and impressive.

meaning: To greatly annoy someone and make them angry.
example: The music coming from next door was driving them up the wall. It was way too loud and was disturbing them as they tried to work.

meaning: Something is making me extremely annoyed and frustrated, or perhaps angry.
example: That noise coming from the radio is driving me nuts! It sounds like nails on a blackboard!

meaning: Come over to one's house in an informal way.
example: Brenda dropped by my friend's house the other day.

meaning: Something so insignificant that it won't make any real difference.
example: They decided to begin a serious fundraising effort for the charity. The amount they'd received so far was just a drop in the bucket compared to what they needed.

meaning: To write to someone, probably just a short letter or message.
example: Maude set aside some time to drop her friend a line. It was just a few words, but that was all that was needed.

meaning: Very beautiful or gorgeous.
example: Lots of people were jealous of the model when she was growing up. She was drop-dead gorgeous

meaning: Rehearsal.
example: The band is doing a dry run of the show tonight. They always make sure to practice their numbers in advance.

meaning: Well-organized and prepared.
example: Ruth has everything ready that she needs to apply to college. She really has her ducks in a row.

meaning: To have a trait or characteristic that seems basic to the individual's nature or that is ingrained in some way.
example: The entire family are dyed-in-the-wool tennis fans

meaning: An extremely eager person.
example: They said that the students who arrived for class half an hour early were eager beavers.

meaning: You get something easily and you lose it easily.
example: They lost all their winnings from the contest. Oh well! I guess easy come, easy go.

meaning: Move or act more slowly and carefully.
example: Could you pick up that heavy box for me, please? Easy does it! You don't want to hurt your back.

meaning: To admit that you were mistaken about something.
example: Noah was completely wrong in the approach he took. He's definitely going to have to eat crow and admit his error.

meaning: To eat very little.
example: My friend doesn't eat very much at lunch. Honestly, he eats like a bird.

meaning: To eat a lot and have a big appetite.
example: That guy has at least five meals a day. He eats like a horse!

meaning: When someone says that they will “eat my hat” if something happens, they are essentially saying that they think it will not happen.
example: I will eat my hat if he wins the competition. It's just impossible!

meaning: To have to deal with hopeless circumstances or suffer without saying anything. Often said triumphantly.
example: “Joey loves me, so eat your heart out,” Sarah said to her best friend Lucy, knowing that Lucy was actually in love with Joey herself.

meaning: To seem, or be, embarrassed.
example: The politician had egg on his face; he messed up several lines his last speech.

meaning: A very short speech in which you promote your capabilities and discuss how you can benefit an individual or organization; used in job searches.
example: I quickly started my elevator pitch, but he had to walk away after getting a text. I don't think I'll get the job.

meaning: The show is over now. Everything is over.
example: It looks like Elvis has left the building. There's no sign of Mr. Smith anywhere.

idiom: Every cloud has a silver lining
meaning: Good things can arise as a result of, or after, bad things.
example: I know you're disappointed about missing out on taking a vacation, but remember that every cloud has a silver lining. Maybe you'll get a promotion.

meaning: Everyone has a chance of some success, of some kind, at least once.
example: He said the guy had a bit of success in something and that every dog has his day.

meaning: Occasionally.
example: We go to that park every now and then. It's not something we can do all the time.

meaning: Pretty much everything has been included.
example: I always find it a bit difficult to pack for vacation. It's because I always want to pack everything but the kitchen sink!

meaning: The exact amount of coins needed.
example: It's best to have exact change when you want to take the bus.

meaning: Excuse the fact that I used an offensive (swear) word.
example: Sorry. Pardon my French. I don't usually use swear words like that!

meaning: Face the consequences of something you have done.
example: My sister was really offended when I wasn't able to attend her event last week. I think I'll have to call her and face the music.

meaning: To be done fairly and correctly.
example: Your share of the pie is one quarter, because there are four people. That's fair and square!

meaning: Average in quality.
example: The quality of the car was fair to middling. It was just average.

meaning: A person who only acts like a friend when things are going well and they can benefit in some way.
example: Linda was a fair-weather friend. I only ever heard from her when she could get something from me.

meaning: Something that comes to be ignored.
example: Our concern about the first issue fell by the wayside when we heard about the new problem.

meaning: To fail to stick to a determination to do something, for example, to give up alcohol (for an alcoholic) or smoking.
example: Brittany had been determined to quit smoking but she ended up falling off the wagon. She was determined to get back on it again, though, and become a non-smoker.

meaning: Someone is not listening to what is said.
example: I tried to give her some good advice but it seemed to fall on deaf ears. She didn't listen

meaning: You begin to like or respect someone less the better you know them.
example: Bill didn't like his best friend’s others friends after he got to know them. But maybe it's because familiarity breeds contempt.

meaning: Very fancy and maybe ostentatious.
example: The family was always showing off the things they had and making a big deal of it. People called their kids fancy pants at school.

meaning: Someone who is obsessed with fashion, probably to the point where they go overboard and end up looking worse.
example: We weren't impressed by what we saw at last night's fashion show. It looked like a parade of fashion victims.

meaning: A wealthy, but usually very lazy, person.
example: People thought the leaders of the company were all fat cats. They were wealthy but never seemed to do very much of anything.

meaning: Something one is proud of.
example: The fact that he got the promotion was truly a feather in his cap. He was very proud of it.

meaning: To gather up resources to ensure future comfort. Often used sarcastically, implying that someone is doing this in a dishonest or exploitative way.
example: We think that he was trying to get as much money as he could, even if it meant that we didn't receive our fair share. He was definitely feathering his nest.

meaning: To eat a large amount of food, probably in a frantic manner. Also refers to consuming anything in a frantic way, such as the public being in a feeding frenzy about the latest celebrity story.
example: It seemed like all the magazines were in a feeding frenzy for stories about my favorite celebrity. There were stories printed all over the place.

meaning: To feel extremely good—both in the way you feel inside and the way you look.
example: I felt like a million dollars when I was dressed up for the banquet last night.

meaning: To feel the effects of a lack of money or other resources.
example: The business had been feeling the pinch. Money was in short supply and they weren't sure how they could continue to offer their services.

meaning: To feel or look extremely tired and drained.
example: Jesse's flu seems to be over, but he still looks like death warmed over. His face appears so tired and pale.

meaning: Feeling sad or depressed.
example: She's feeling a bit blue right now. We're trying to cheer her up.

meaning: A minor car accident.
example: We got into a fender bender yesterday. Just a minor car accident. It was stressful at the time, though.

meaning: An enjoyable circumstance or day.
example: We had a field day on our excursion last week. We had a great time.

meaning: To enjoy an extremely short period of fame or recognition of some sort.
example: James is doing really well with his YouTube channel. But you know what they say: everyone has their fifteen minutes of fame.

meaning: To deal with a difficult situation that becomes harder as you go.
example: My sister told me that what I was attempting to do would probably end up being an uphill battle. It would be extremely difficult and the number of obstacles would only increase the longer that I tried to do it

meaning: To fight hard and determinedly.
example: I was determined to succeed in this field, deciding that I'd fight tooth and nail if I had to.

meaning: To guess the content of missing information.
example: We were left to fill in the blanks with the missing information about the course.

meaning: Extremely wealthy
example: The Addison family owned two houses and five cars. Everyone said they were filthy rich.

meaning: Adjust and become accustomed to new circumstances or expectations.
example: It took Mark quite a long time to find his feet in his new career, but he's doing great now!

meaning: Delicious food (very informal).
example: I wish you could have come to the barbeque the other day. The food was finger lickin' good!

meaning: To be in an environment that you're not used to or that you don't readily fit into.
example: He's a fish out of water here. He doesn't know anything about this field and doesn't understand its culture.

meaning: Seems suspicious.
example: Do you think the situation seemed kind of fishy? I thought something appeared suspicious.

meaning: In excellent health.
example: When I went for a checkup with the doctor, he said there were a few problems. I was surprised. I had thought I was as fit as a fiddle.

meaning: Extremely angry.
example: I was fit to be tied when they told me the news. I don't think I've ever been so angry.

meaning: Very brief bursts of motion.
example: Louise progressed in her career in fits and starts. She'd make a lot of progress at certain points but then fight to get any further for a while.

meaning: The signs of hair starting to grow back on the face of a man who has recently shaved.
example: Daniel suddenly realized that he had forgotten to shave. He definitely had quite a bit of five o'clock shadow.

meaning: To ruin someone's chance of success, often in revenge for a grievance.
example: I can't believe that she treated me that way. I'm going to fix her wagon. She can't get away with this.

meaning: Inflexible in the ways you do things.
example: Betty always did things the same way. She was very fixed in her ways.

meaning: Something that is trendy or fashionable to care about at the moment.
example: Interest in that hobby is really popular right now, but I actually think it's just the flavor of the month.

meaning: A market where people buy and sell secondhand and/or inexpensive goods.
example: We went shopping this weekend, but instead of the mall we went to the nearby flea market. It was fun to look for some deals! My friend found a vintage hat.

meaning: People who are related to you, or anyone or anything that is alive.
example: My cousin was happy to do the favor for me. After all, she said, I'm her flesh and blood.

idiom: Fly in the face of something
meaning: To act in opposition to something or to show disrespect for someone or something.
example: The statement he made flew in the face of everything his friends expected of him. They were very disappointed.

meaning: Something unpleasant in a situation that is otherwise entirely pleasant.
example: The lack of money was a fly in the ointment. It could ruin their plans to travel to Europe this summer.

meaning: To suddenly become extremely angry, especially if overreacting to something.
example: Wow! I was really surprised at how they got so angry about this. They really flew off the handle!

meaning: To escape.
example: Jack was tired of the job he had held for twenty years and felt he wanted to advance in the field. He decided to fly the coop and look for a position elsewhere.

meaning: Markedly untrustworthy or undependable.
example: The restaurant seemed like a fly-by-night. The furnishings were in a state of disrepair and the staff were extremely rude. It seemed like they could close down tomorrow.

meaning: To show rage.
example: David was incredibly angry about the situation. It seemed like he was almost foaming at the mouth.

meaning: To follow the same path in life as someone else.
example: Liam was a plumber. His son decided to follow in his father's footsteps and become a plumber, too.

meaning: To follow the direction of people gaining large amounts of money when investigating corruption.
example: The investigators always remembered to "follow the money" when investigating financial crimes.

meaning: Something that you or others think is worth carefully thinking about.
example: When my best friends gave me their opinion, I realized that it was certainly food for thought.

meaning: To joke around and act in a jovial or silly way.
example: The high school students were fooling around outside the school, joking with each other and laughing.

meaning: Something that looks like gold but isn't.
example: They thought that the opportunity would be very lucrative. However, it ended up being fool's gold.

meaning: To find an opportunity to make progress in a desired direction.
example: Isabella explained that she had hoped to be offered a better position with the company. The job she got, though, is a foot in the door.

meaning: To be free of care and worry, able to have fun all the time.
example: Patricia had a wonderful life. She had lots of money and didn't have to worry about anything. Most of her time was spent shopping and traveling. She was footloose and fancy-free.

meaning: Something one says when one is frustrated or at the end of one's patience.
example: For crying out loud! Why are you still worrying about this? There's no reason to!

meaning: Something one says when one is frustrated or in a state of disbelief.
example: For goodness' sake, why do you feel the need to go shopping again today? You bought so much yesterday!

meaning: Something one says when one is frustrated or in a state of disbelief.
example: For heaven's sake, why are you doing this? It's a mistake.

meaning: A waste of energy and time, or confused and disorganized.
example: I think that's for the birds. It's a waste of time and doesn't make any sense.

meaning: To pay money (often a large or unaffordable amount) for something.
example: They went to a fancy restaurant and ended up having to fork over much more money than they had anticipated. It was probably because of the wine they ordered.

meaning: Taking risks can lead to success
example: I tend to worry about taking risks but I need to remember that fortune favors the bold.

meaning: A very short nap, usually during the day
