example: I'm very tired. I think I'll lie down and try to get forty winks.

meaning: To become very angry, worried, or frightened.
example: I thought she would be okay with the news but she started to freak out! She seemed really worried.

meaning: From the very beginning.
example: That employee has been difficult to deal with since day one. He’s been giving us problems since we hired him.

meaning: To go from being poor to wealthy.
example: They had always been good at computer programming. It was their skills that helped them go from rags to riches with an amazing tech company.

meaning: From the beginning
example: Andrew left his job last week. He said he knew from the get-go that it wouldn't work out.

meaning: From the very beginning.
example: There have been problems with this project from the word go. There were issues ingrained in it from the beginning.

meaning: Occasionally.
example: I like to go for nature hikes from time to time. It's not something I do all the time, just sometimes on cooler days.

meaning: An excessively old-fashioned person.
example: Mr. Roberts is so old-fashioned and inflexible with his thinking. He's definitely a fuddy-duddy.

meaning: Doesn't know what he or she is talking about. Offensive in most contexts.
example: Don't tell anyone I said this, but I think that professor is full of crap.

meaning: To be a person who talks a lot but has no idea what they are talking about and/or is arrogant.
example: The speaker was full of hot air. He was arrogant and didn't seem to have any real idea of what he was talking about.

meaning: Enthusiastically moving forward.
example: Yes, we've decided to move forward with the business. Full steam ahead!

meaning: To advance and make progress.
example: The company has really been gaining ground lately. It's doing well.

meaning: Gave someone approval.
example: Her parents gave her the thumbs-up when she asked if they'd allow her to go camping this summer.

meaning: To gain control or understanding of something.
example: It took her a long time to get a handle on the situation. It was difficult to control.

meaning: To obtain possession of something.
example: I couldn't get a hold of any of that brand of perfume yesterday. It seems to be unavailable right now.

meaning: To gain control of yourself.
example: Get a hold of yourself! There's no reason to be so upset.

meaning: To start being active again in something.
example: It's time to get a move on! If we don't leave now, we'll never get there on time.

meaning: Gain more energy after feeling tired.
example: I had to take a break during my run. I needed to get my second wind.

idiom: Get a taste of your own medicine
meaning: Experience being treated badly, as you have treated other people.
example: We think you've been really mean to Mary lately. Maybe one day you'll get a taste of your own medicine.

meaning: To be able to say something when someone won't stop talking.
example: It's hard to talk to James. He never lets you get a word in edgewise.

meaning: To have a harmonious relationship with someone; to refrain from argument or conflict.
example: Mike and Mitchell get along really well. They never argue.

meaning: To contact a person again to tell them something in the near future.
example: Yes, I got her phone message. I'm going to get back to her tomorrow.

meaning: To get down to the basics of a situation.
example: I think we've been explaining things to the employees in an excessively complicated way. Let's just get down to brass tacks.

meaning: Start doing the practical things that need to be done.
example: Let's get down to business! This work has to be done by tomorrow.

idiom: Get down to the nuts and bolts
meaning: To focus on the basics of something or a situation.
example: Let's get down to the nuts and bolts of the issue. It's best to focus on the basics first.

meaning: To get from one place to another.
example: It seems to take a long time to get from A to B in this city. There's too much traffic.

meaning: To get in contact with someone.
example: I tried to call and text her, but I couldn't get hold of Sarah yesterday. I don't know where she is.

meaning: To annoy someone or cause them some kind of irritation or hindrance.
example: Hannah has really been getting in my hair! She's always causing problems for me.

meaning: In a lot of trouble.
example: Michelle has been having a lot of financial trouble with her business. I'm afraid she'll get into deep water with it.

meaning: To express something that has been bothering you or making you sad.
example: Nicole was relieved to express her feelings and get them off her chest. She had been keeping them to herself for a long time and it was a burden.

meaning: Try to understand what one is saying. This is an impolite expression
example: Why can't he understand what I'm saying? I really wish he'd get it through his head.

idiom: Get off on the wrong foot
meaning: To start something the wrong way.
example: They got off on the wrong foot at first, but they became very good friends later on.

meaning: Stop imagining that you are superior.
example: I told Jane to get off her high horse. She always gives the impression that she thinks she's better than I am

meaning: To start something new, such as a new job or occupation.
example: One day, during their internships, the students got their feet wet in the fields they wanted to enter.

meaning: For something to get out of control.
example: Things started quietly early in the evening but the party eventually got out of hand!

meaning: To stop feeling annoyed or upset about something.
example: My brother is still really upset about not making it onto the basketball team. I felt bad for him at first but he needs to get over it.

meaning: To get something for very little money.
example: Do you like my new top? I got it for peanuts yesterday, at a clearance sale.

idiom: Get something out of your system
meaning: To do something you have wanted to do so that you can feel relieved and move on.
example: Anne was quite wild when she was younger, but she wanted to get things out of her system.

meaning: To get permission to proceed.
example: Don't worry! We got the go-head for the project from the boss yesterday. We can start it very soon.

meaning: To get permission to proceed.
example: We got the green light to move forward with the project. Let's get started!

meaning: To become proficient in an activity or task.
example: It took me a few months to get the hang of my new hobby.

meaning: To understand what is communicated.
example: I wish that Ashley would get the message and realize that I don't want to go out every weekend.

meaning: To be fired from one's job.
example: The new employee got the sack the other day. Yes, he got fired.

idiom: Get this show on the road
meaning: To get something started.
example: Let's get started! It's time to get this show on the road.

idiom: Get to the bottom of something
meaning: To understand all the aspects and origins of something.
example: We're determined to find out what caused all of this. We'll get to the bottom of it.

meaning: To more clearly and promptly express what one is saying.
example: She always takes a long time to explain things. It would be better if she made more of an effort to get to the point.

idiom: Get up on the wrong side of bed
meaning: To wake up in a bad mood or to be in a bad mood first thing in the morning.
example: I think Cecilia got out of the wrong side of bed this morning. She was in a terrible mood when I saw her!

meaning: To hear news of something that has been kept secret.
example: I finally got wind of the plans that they are making. I couldn't find out anything about them before.

meaning: To become more alert and make more of an effort to understand what is going on.
example: Look, you don't seem to be keeping up with what you need to know. It's time to get with it.

meaning: Start doing better or you will be in trouble.
example: Robert was in trouble at work. His boss said he had better get his act together or he might get fired.

meaning: For something to make you upset.
example: Nicholas made everyone really frustrated and angry that day. He really got our dander up!

meaning: To make someone annoyed or angry.
example: My friends are nice people but they really frustrated me yesterday. They certainly got my goat when they laughed at my new haircut.

meaning: To come to understand something.
example: This is a really tricky subject. I'm having trouble getting my head around it.

meaning: Managing to survive, especially financially.
example: Ben isn't very happy in his job. He's only making enough to get by. He wants to be more financially successful.

meaning: Something is annoying you to the point that you feel you might lose your temper.
example: This movie is so stupid that it's annoying. I'm telling you, that scene really got on my last nerve.

meaning: Something is making you feel annoyed.
example: That song is getting on my nerves. I’ve already heard it five times today.

meaning: Physical energy.
example: I didn't have enough get-up-and-go to finish it quickly. I lacked the energy.

idiom: Give a run for one's money
meaning: To present a significant challenge to someone.
example: William didn't end up winning the contest but he gave his opponent a real run for his money.

meaning: To express appreciation for someone.
example: That is a challenging academic program. I give props to everyone who has completed it.

meaning: To cause difficulty for someone.
example: The kids gave their parents a hard time when they weren't allowed to go to Disney World.

idiom: Give someone a piece of my mind
meaning: To tell someone you strongly disagree with them and disapprove of something they've done or that they think.
example: I gave the salesperson a piece of my mind the other day when I went in to get a refund for the top I had purchased. All the stitching came out when I washed it!

idiom: Give someone a song and dance
meaning: To waste someone's time instead of giving them an explanation or something else that they require.
example: I asked for an explanation for what happened the other day, but all I got was a song and dance. They didn't take responsibility for anything.

meaning: To give only a very short amount of time to someone.
example: Sarah gave her friend the short shrift. She wouldn't spend enough time with her and wouldn't listen to what she had to say.

idiom: Give someone the benefit of the doubt
meaning: To trust what someone says until you see proof that you shouldn't.
example: Susan gave her friend the benefit of the doubt. She had no reason to disbelieve what she said.

meaning: To ignore or act dismissively toward someone.
example: She had looked forward to seeing her old friend at the reunion, and was surprised she was given the cold shoulder.

meaning: To escape or get away from someone.
example: The college students didn't want to see their professor, so they gave him the slip and left the classroom before he saw them.

meaning: To act in a way that is different from the people around you and to follow your own path.
example: Rose was an independent thinker. She was never afraid to go against the grain and do what she thought was right, even if others disagreed with her.

meaning: To keep trying to do the same thing, with little to no progress
example: I'm sorry, but we just couldn't get it done. We kept going around in circles, trying to decide what we could do to fix the situation.

idiom: Go back to the drawing board
meaning: To completely start over.
example: I don't think this has turned out very well. We'd better go back to the drawing board.

meaning: To go crazy.
example: They got so excited and acted so strangely that I almost started to wonder if they'd gone bananas!

meaning: For a business to fail.
example: The store around the corner went belly up just a few months after it opened.

meaning: To go crazy
example: She went bonkers when she found out that she failed the exam.

meaning: To suddenly and completely stop a practice, often smoking or drinking.
example: Laureen had smoked for ten years and knew that she had to quit. She had tried to go cold turkey several times but hadn't succeeded, so she decided to find some help.

meaning: To fail in a spectacular way.
example: I thought my plans would work out but, sadly, everything went down in flames.

meaning: To go away; to leave someone alone.
example: Joseph got angry at his friend the other day and told him to go fly a kite.

meaning: To go away; to leave someone alone.
example: Anthony was in a bad mood yesterday. When I tried to talk to him, he got mad at me and told me to go fry an egg!

meaning: To become erratic and behave very strangely.
example: Joe and Tom were acting really strangely last week. I told people that they had gone haywire!

meaning: To do something alone, with little or no help.
example: We decided to go it alone with the business. We knew we could do it by ourselves.

meaning: To try to do something without being properly prepared for it.
example: I made sure to read the instruction booklet and understand what I was doing before I tried. I didn't want to go off half-cocked.

meaning: To panic or act irrationally.
example: I was really worried about Alex the other day. It seemed like he was about to go off the deep end after he learned the bad news.

idiom: Go on a wild goose chase
meaning: To undertake a pointless endeavor.
example: Connie went out to run some errands and ended up going on a wild goose chase. There was one item on her list that she couldn't find anywhere.

meaning: To make an extra effort to do something for someone else.
example: I went out of my way to help her study for the final exam. I didn't have to do that, but wanted to be of assistance.

meaning: To put oneself in a difficult position just to help someone else or to assist with something.
example: Derek went on a limb for me. He didn't have to help me get out of the situation but he did, even though it caused him some difficulties.

meaning: To do something in excess.
example: I'm afraid I might have gone overboard with my shopping the other day! I bought a designer handbag and designer shoes!

meaning: To go crazy in an aggressive way.
example: Lydia didn't tell me about what was happening. Maybe she was afraid that I'd go postal? Just kidding!

meaning: When something starts to go badly.
example: Everything with the new venture seemed to be going so well, but it suddenly started to go south.

meaning: To do more than is required.
example: Meredith always went the extra mile with her job. That's why she was considered such a great employee.

meaning: Do the whole thing and go to the fullest extent.
example: Her daughter decided she wanted to go the whole hog with her upcoming birthday party. She wanted it to be really exciting and to have everything you could imagine.

idiom: Go through it with a fine-tooth comb
meaning: To explore a topic, or object, in an extremely thorough way.
example: The detectives looked at the situation extremely carefully. They went through it with a fine-tooth comb.

idiom: Go to hell in a handbasket
meaning: Headed for disaster or deteriorating significantly.
example: Have you looked at the building project on the corner lately? It really seems like it's going to hell in a handbasket.

meaning: To feel frantic and/or not be able to cope with something.
example: Poor Nicole! She seemed to fall to pieces the other day when her boyfriend broke up with her.

meaning: To significantly deteriorate in condition or circumstances.
example: Mike was terrified when he found out that he'd lost his job. He was afraid that he'd end up going to the dogs.

meaning: To do something very enthusiastically or to get permission to go overboard
example: They told me to go to town with what I wanted to do. They liked my enthusiasm.

meaning: There’s a possibility of something disappearing or significantly deteriorating.
example: Linda was afraid that her chances of getting her dream job had gone up in smoke. It seemed like they'd been destroyed.

meaning: To take an easygoing attitude and just go along with whatever is happening.
example: Robert overreacted a bit at first and got pretty upset about the situation, but he decided to try to just go with the flow.

meaning: Something is obvious and therefore doesn't really need to be said.
example: It goes without saying that I'll want to relax this weekend. You see how tired I am.

meaning: The most wonderful period of a stretch of time.
example: Ava loved her time in college. She considered it the golden age of her life.

meaning: An incredible opportunity.
example: The job offer was a golden opportunity.

meaning: Someone who is generally a good and reliable person but who has some peculiarities or eccentricities.
example: He's can be little odd on occasion, but it's definitely a good egg. He's very sweet and just a little awkward.

meaning: That's great and you should be proud of yourself.
example: You got an A+ on your exam? Good for you. That's amazing!

meaning: To be glad that something or someone one dislikes is gone.
example: They are gone now? Good riddance! They were so rude to me.

idiom: Good things come to those who wait

example: Don't lose heart! Good things come to those who wait. You're sure to find good career opportunities soon. Just keep trying!

meaning: That's useful to be aware of
example: Oh, you're going this weekend? Good to know. I might go too, then.

meaning: An expression usually used by children. A child (especially a girl) who is very good and never misbehaves.
example: Our son said that there's a girl in his class who never, ever misbehaves and who always helps the teacher during recess. He calls her a goody, goody gumdrop, but I told him he should be like that, too.

meaning: To act in a silly way and to take a break from more serious things.
example: The professor became annoyed when some of the students in his class wouldn't stop goofing off.

meaning: To not be held responsible for something.
example: I couldn't believe it when they got off scot-free! They did something serious that deserved to be punished.

meaning: To be questioned intensely and persistently.
example: Her parents gave her the third degree when she came home too late the other night. They asked her questions for at least an hour.

meaning: To make upset or to offend.

meaning: The person you go to for help with a certain endeavor or issue.
example: He's their go-to-guy for office equipment problems. He's a great repairman.

meaning: Desperate to find solutions.
example: They're having a difficult time. They've been grasping at straws, desperate to find a solution.

meaning: A work shift between about midnight and eight in the morning, when most other people are asleep.
example: They found out that they'd need to work the graveyard first when they first started their new job. They weren't looking forward to having to work all night!

meaning: Something that allows people to make lots of money with hardly any, or no, effort.

meaning: Something that cannot really be thought of in black-and-white terms. There are both bad and good aspects to the situation.
example: My opinion was that it was a gray area. It was neither completely good nor completely bad.

meaning: A mechanic (this expression might be considered dismissive if said to a mechanic).
example: The mechanic seemed offended when I called him a grease monkey. I won't do that again.

meaning: Very fast.
example: The race car was like greased lightning! It was amazingly fast.

meaning: Intelligent people often have the same ideas.
example: Wow, I can't believe we both had the same idea at the same time! Great minds think alike!

meaning: Feeling nauseous or sick to your stomach.

meaning: A room where people wait before they go on a TV or radio show.
example: The stars of the show are waiting in the green room. They're ready to go on.

meaning: Talent with gardening.
example: Louise always has such a beautiful garden. She has a green thumb.

meaning: To be extremely jealous or envious.
example: My friends were green with envy when they saw my new designer shoes.

meaning: To deal with something and endure it without complaint.
example: I was upset when they told me to just grin and bear it. This problem is interfering with my life.

meaning: Someone who considers himself or herself to be experimented on in some way.
example: They felt as if they'd been used as guinea pigs when they realized the new product had been released without the company knowing whether or not it was actually safe to use.

meaning: Enthusiastic.
example: Tommy is certainly gung ho about his upcoming vacation in the Caribbean. He's so enthusiastic. We're a bit jealous!

meaning: An intuition.
example: I just had a gut feeling that I shouldn't go shopping today. I'm not sure why. It was just my intuition.

meaning: An alcoholic beverage of some kind taken in an attempt to cure a hangover.
example: Bill woke up with a terrible hangover. He didn't make the wisest decision, however, when he had some hair of the dog. That drink just made it worse.

meaning: A very narrow space.
example: I felt there was only a hair's breadth of difference between the two approaches. They seemed almost exactly the same.

idiom: Half a mind to do something
meaning: Thinking about doing something.
example: I have half a mind to learn how to play tennis. All my friends love the sport and I wish I could take part in it with them.

meaning: Half of the effort or work required.
example: Learning how to do this is half the battle. Once you've become good at it, you'll be able to work much more quickly.

meaning: Inadequately thought-out or planned.
example: I think it's a terrible plan. Honestly, it's half-baked. Didn't anyone think it out?

meaning: To negotiate and arrive at a deal.
example: They managed to hammer out a great deal with the salesperson.

meaning: Very close.
example: The two parts of the business worked hand in glove. They were necessary for each other.

meaning: Very quickly.
example: We were surprised by how much money they spent yesterday. It seemed like they were paying out cash hand over fist!

meaning: Stay determined and persistent.
example: I know things are difficult right now but hang in there!

meaning: Just wait for something to happen.
example: It's okay! Hang tight. It'll definitely happen eventually.

meaning: Very cheerful and happy.
example: Don't worry about him! He's always so happy-go-lucky; it seems like he can deal with almost anything with a smile on his face.

meaning: To use selling techniques that are relatively aggressive or pushy.
example: The used car salesperson always used a hard sell when dealing with customers. That's why people tried to avoid him. He was pushy.

meaning: Something that is difficult to take or accept.
example: The fact that he hadn't done well in the course was a bitter pill to swallow. He didn't want to accept it.

meaning: Rushing through something will likely lead to mistakes.
example: Susan tried to hurry as she made the dress, but her friend advised her that haste makes waste.

meaning: To be upset about something and to perhaps desire revenge of some kind.
example: Laura definitely has an axe to grind with Lindsey. It seems like Lindsay did something to upset her in the past and she still hasn't let it go.

meaning: Eccentric or crazy in a harmless way.
example: That professor seems weird. I think he has bats in his belfry!

meaning: To be in severe difficulties.
example: I'm afraid there could be hell to pay if we don't get this done by the deadline. We'll be in a lot of trouble.

meaning: To thoroughly understand something.
example: Don't worry about Isabella. She has the instructions for the task down pat.

idiom: Have the world by the tail
meaning: To be doing remarkably well with something; to be in control of one's life and prospects.
example: It seems like Madison has the world by the tail. She appears to be in control of everything and is immensely successful.

meaning: To have time away from work.
example: Marissa has a bit of time off work. She is planning to use it for a short vacation to a nearby city.

meaning: To be clumsy, especially while dancing.
example: I'm a terrible dancer! I have two left feet.

idiom: Have your head in the clouds
meaning: To fail to concentrate or to live in a dreamworld.
example: Max always seemed to have his head in the clouds. He never appeared to focus and seemed to live in a dreamworld.

idiom: He has bigger fish to fry
meaning: He/she has more important issues to deal with than what we are currently discussing.
example: Don't bother him with that problem right now. He is very busy and has bigger fish to fry.

idiom: He who laughs last laughs loudest
meaning: I'll get some kind of revenge for what you have done.
example: You think that you've outsmarted me, but remember: he who laughs last laughs loudest.

meaning: Vastly superior.
example: The literary critic thought that the first book was head and shoulders above the second. It was superior in every way.

meaning: Someone in the highest position of power within an organization or company.We told them they would need to ask our boss about it. She's the head honcho, after all, and makes all the important decisions.
example: We told them they would need to ask our boss about it. She's the head honcho, after all, and makes all the important decisions.

meaning: Tending to live in the imagination and not firmly grounded in reality.
example: Noreen's head is always in the clouds. She seems to live mostly in her imagination. I can't get her to think of practical things.

meaning: To fall, or to be, deeply in love.
example: The couple is very much in love. They are head over heels for each other.

meaning: An update that provides new knowledge or understanding of something.
example: I asked her to give me a heads-up if anything about the situation changed.

meaning: To hear a rumor about someone or something.
example: Olivia wondered how Emily had heard about her news. Emily explained that she heard it on the grapevine, through rumors from friends.

idiom: Hear something straight from the horse's mouth
meaning: To hear information directly from the individual involved.
example: It's true, I promise you. He's going to Europe this summer. I got it straight from the horse's mouth.

meaning: A creepy feeling that might make you shudder.
example: Lizzy hates any kind of spider or insect. They always give her the heebiejeebies! If she sees one, she’ll ask someone else to deal with it!

meaning: Sometimes/occasionally, or in several different places.
example: I buy new shoes here and there. I don't go shopping very often because trying on new shoes takes too long.

idiom: He's a chip off the old block
meaning: A son who is similar to his father.
example: Look at him, fishing like he's been doing it forever! I can’t believe this is his first try. He must be a chip off the old block.

idiom: He's not playing with a full deck
meaning: He's not very smart.
example: Derek told me the news, so I'm not sure if I really believe it's true. After all, he's not playing with a full deck.

meaning: Someone who is very irrational, even crazy.
example: I can't believe he'd run in front of traffic like that! He must be off his rocker.

meaning: To live in a luxurious way.
example: Their family has lots of money, and they always seem to live high on the hog. They went on four vacations last year.

meaning: Large and impressive.
example: We couldn't believe it when we saw the house! It is truly high, wide, and handsome. I've never known anyone with such an impressive piece of property.

meaning: To get really upset and to show it.
example: I couldn't believe how upset they got! They never stopped talking loudly; they even shouted about their frustration. For adults, they threw quite a hissy fit.

meaning: To have a perfect understanding of something or to do something perfectly.
example: Olivia was very smart. She seemed to get everything right at work, constantly hitting things on the nose.

meaning: To get in contact with someone. For example to email, text, or call an acquaintance.
example: Hit me up if you'd like to join the team.

meaning: To come upon something of significant value.
example: We were so lucky we found that the other day. We certainly hit pay dirt.

meaning: To insult or otherwise treat a person in an unfair way.
example: I can't believe what Brad said to his best friend. That insult was really below the belt, wasn't it?

meaning: To study intensely.
example: I have three exams coming up next week. I'm really nervous and have to hit the books soon.

meaning: To get extremely angry.
example: When they asked how she reacted, I had to say the truth: she hit the ceiling! Yes, she was extremely angry.

meaning: To go to bed.
example: I had a long day and I'm so tired. I think I'll hit the hay soon.

meaning: To come into possession of wealth or something of great value.
example: Lisa hoped that maybe one day she would win the jackpot on the lottery, and use all her winnings to travel and and luxurious cars.

idiom: Hit the nail on the head
meaning: You've figured out the exact truth.
example: I haven't been able to figure it out, but you have hit the nail on the head!

meaning: To start on a journey.
example: Hurry up! It's time to hit the road if we're going to get there in time.

meaning: To go to bed and sleep.
example: I've had a very long day. I think I'll hit the sack and see you in the morning.

meaning: Magic of some sort, or perhaps trickery.
example: I couldn't help but joke that they must have used some hocus-pocus. Why else would their professor give them an extension on the assignment?

meaning: To take responsibility for a place or maintain an activity while someone is away.
example: Could you possibly hold the fort while I go to the store? I just need you to watch my dog.

meaning: Wait for a bit before acting.
example: Hold your horses! You shouldn't send a reply to that email until you've had time to calm down and think about it.

meaning: Stop talking, especially about something specific.
example: Make sure you hold your tongue about this. I don't want you to mention anything about it to my brother.

meaning: Having to be responsible for something.
example: Kevin ended up holding the bag for the team project. The others just weren't responsible enough.

meaning: Extremely angry.
example: Heather was hopping mad when she found out that her friend had talked about personal business behind her back.

meaning: To act in a silly way.
example: The kids weren't really fighting. They were just horsing around

meaning: Something that is very different, especially with regard to a situation or an idea in the context of a debate.
example: He didn't feel that the situations were comparable. Each was a horse of a different color, he said.

meaning: An issue that people tend to have strong opinions on.
example: Politics are a hot-button issue in the area. Everyone has an opinion and people get into arguments

meaning: Angry.
example: They got hot under the collar when they discovered that someone had deliberately ruined their project.

meaning: An important and powerful person in a particular place or situation.
example: He's a local hotshot because of all the businesses he owns. He's very influential.

idiom: How do you like them apples
meaning: An expression used to boast about/gloat over something to someone. Can also be used to express surprise.
example: Nancy and Alexis didn't get along. They were always competing to see who could be more successful. When Nancy got an amazing new job, she couldn't wait to tell Alexis. “How do you like them apples?” she planned to say

meaning: Happy and comfortable.
example: There was no need for you to worry about me being uncomfortable in my hotel room while on vacation. Everything was hunky-dory!

meaning: Something is unbelievable or terrible.
example: I'm sorry to hear that you didn't get into the program on the third try. I just can't imagine.

idiom: I don't have two nickels to rub together
meaning: A drastic lack of money.
example: My friends said I should go with them on vacation to the islands. I had to explain to them that I don't have two nickels to rub together.

meaning: I'm terrible or disappointing at something.
example: I suck at basketball. I can never get the ball in the hoop.

meaning: I am not naïve.
example: Can you believe that ridiculous trick the salesperson tried to play on me? I wasn't born yesterday!

meaning: Something extra that is good, that comes along with something else that's very good, too.
example: We're going to France this year, and to put the icing on the cake, we're visiting Spain, too.

idiom: I'd give my right hand to
meaning: Would give up anything to be able to do something or to have something.
example: She said she'd give her right hand to go to Europe for six months! It was her dream to explore France and Portugal.

idiom: Idle hands are the devil's tools
meaning: Idleness can lead to boredom, and that might result in someone doing stupid or bad things.
example: What are you doing? Nothing? You should be doing something. Remember that idle hands are the devil's tools.

idiom: If I had a nickel for every time something happened
meaning: A specific thing happens a lot.
example: If I had a nickel for every time Hannah boasted about her vacations, I'd have a thousand dollars. She is always bragging!

meaning: If the worst possible scenario happens.
example: If worst comes to worst, we'll have to do something more drastic to deal with the situation.

idiom: If you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen
meaning: If you don’t want to deal with the difficulties required to complete a task, then don't bother to do it at all.
example: Gary was always complaining about the work involved in preparing for his dream career. His instructors told him that if he couldn’t stand the heat, to get out of the kitchen! Their declaration made him try harder to deal with it.

idiom: If you play your cards right
meaning: If you do the right things.
example: If you play your cards right, I think you'll get a promotion at work this year.

meaning: It's easier not to know.
example: Sometimes not knowing everything about a situation can make things easier for you. You know what they say: ignorance is bliss.

meaning: I feel like I'm going crazy.
example: I think I'm losing it! I've forgotten to do the gardening for the last few days in a row.

meaning: To be in a tricky position or situation.
example: I decided I needed to help my friends. They were in a bind and needed some assistance to get out of it.

meaning: To be in a difficult situation that may be difficult to get out of.
example: Her best friend was always there for her. She could always count on her when she was in a jam.

meaning: In a concise way.
example: It would take me a long time to explain the whole thing, so I'll just put it in a nutshell for you and be brief

meaning: If necessary, for example, in an emergency.
example: I realized I didn't have one of the ingredients in the recipe, but I looked online and found out I could use a substitute in a pinch.

meaning: Stuck in a mundane routine.
example: Edward realized he was in a rut with his job. The work was boring and he wanted to look for a change.

meaning: To have ultimate authority over something, someone, or a group of people
example: Our teacher left the most responsible student in charge while he left the classroom for a moment.

meaning: At the highest level of intensity or activity.
example: The summer season was in full swing at the tourist destination when they arrived for their holiday.

meaning: To get into a much faster pace.
example: Angela's plans are going exactly as she wanted. Everything seems to be going into high gear.

meaning: In trouble.
example: He has made a lot of mistakes on the accounts, so I think he's going to be in hot water at work.

meaning: In my opinion.
example: You asked me for my opinion, and so I'll tell you. In my book, you shouldn't go out dancing tonight when you have a test in two days

meaning: In an area in which one feels comfortable and/or knowledgeable.
example: Danielle was really in her element when teaching music. She was so good at it, and it made her feel good about herself.

meaning: To feel blissfully happy, especially about a certain situation or outcome.
example: The kids were in seventh heaven when they found out they were going to Disney World this summer.

meaning: There is a lot of something.
example: She had been hoping her project would be well-received and was pleased with how successful it was. She got praise in spades!

meaning: Laughing uncontrollably.
example: The comedian had me in stitches with his hilarious jokes.

meaning: Certain to be successful.
example: Don't worry about our presentation tomorrow. It's in the bag! We're sure to do great, as we've prepared so carefully.

meaning: To have more money than you owe.
example: Audrey is really happy that her finances are back in order again. She says it feels so good to finally be in the black.

meaning: In a very isolated and rural area.
example: Her family lived out in the boondocks. That's why it was hard to get to, and find, their house.

meaning: To have (probably unexpectedly) received—or to be about to receive—a large, or relatively large, amount of money.
example: We're going to have lots of fun when we go on our trip. We're in the chips, so we'll have plenty to spend!

meaning: Someone is mad at you and probably ignoring you
example: Mark is in the doghouse right now. His girlfriend is really angry with him.

idiom: In the heat of the moment
meaning: Feeling negatively overwhelmed by current circumstances.
example: He ended up blurting something out that he shouldn't have during the meeting. It was in the heat of the moment. He didn't take the time to think it through first.

meaning: At all.
example: I don't think he wants to be a doctor in the least. He's not interested in science.

meaning: Over the long-term.
example: I know it's a difficult decision to make, but I think it'll be the right one in the long run. Eventually, you'll see the benefits.

meaning: To be aware of what is going on.
example: I'm sick right now, but I've asked my co-workers to keep me in the loop about what is going on at the office.

meaning: Just in time.
example: We arrived at the theatre in the nick of time—just one minute before the show was scheduled to start.

meaning: To be healthy or in excellent condition.
example: No need to worry about Jacqueline. She's in the pink right now.

meaning: To be in debt.
example: Tom's in the red for quite a bit of money because he overspent on his cruise.

meaning: In a rural area with not much going on.
example: It was a much longer drive to the dinner party last night than we had anticipated. Their house is way out in the sticks!

meaning: Some kind of obstruction.
example: There were lots of people in the way when we were trying to get into the popular nightclub.

idiom: It ain't over till the fat lady sings
meaning: This has not ended yet.
example: She thinks that she will definitely win the contest, but it's not over till the fat lady sings.

idiom: It is a poor workman who blames his tools
meaning: Don't cast blame elsewhere if you can't do the job right.
example: They did a really bad job on the roof and blamed other factors. I told them it's a poor workman who blames his tools.

idiom: It is always darkest before the dawn
meaning: The most difficult times come before much better ones.
example: I know you're going through a really terrible time, but try to stay positive. Remember that it's always darkest before the dawn.

idiom: It takes one to know one
meaning: If you call me a name, you must be what you have called me.
example: Bullies called the little boy names. He told them that it takes one to know one

meaning: Both people are responsible; you cannot place the blame on just one person.
example: Jane tried to blame the whole thing on Anna, but everyone knows that it takes two to tango.

meaning: Feeling restless and wanting to get up and move around.
example: The presentation went on for a very long time. I enjoyed it, but I must admit I got itchy feet about an hour in.

meaning: Something that is very simple and easy to do.
example: I did that project for a course last year. Don't worry about it. It's a piece of cake.

meaning: It's a hot day.
example: We're in the middle of a heat wave here. Today is a a scorcher!

meaning: An important project or some other task must be completed very soon.
example: Things are extremely busy at work at the moment. Many deadlines are coming up quickly. It's crunch time!

meaning: Something is secure or certain.
example: There's no need to worry about it. It's in the bag and sure to be successful.

idiom: It's no skin off my nose
meaning: Something that doesn't bother, or negatively affect, me.
example: Diane was worried that I would be upset about it. She was surprised when I told her it was no skin off my nose

meaning: It's not difficult to understand.
example: This furniture is easy to put together. It's not rocket science.

meaning: It's raining heavily outside.
example: I don't think they'll go for a walk this morning. Have you looked outside? It's raining cats and dogs!

meaning: To work and exist in a space that is held above the concerns of the rest of society. This phrase is usually applied to professors in a college or university.
example: He doesn't understand anything about real life. He's spent the last thirty years in an ivory tower.

meaning: Crossing the street at a place other than the crosswalk.
example: You should try not to jaywalk. It could be dangerous. You're probably better off crossing at the crosswalk, instead.

meaning: Someone who is new to a place or situation. Tends to be said with sarcasm.
example: I'm not worried about the competition his new business will pose. He's just a Jonny-come-lately.

meaning: Always, or almost always, with a certain person.
example: Lynn and Margaret are really close friends. It seems like they're always together. I say that they're joined at the hip.

meaning: Fooling me about something.
example: Are you sure it's true? Or are you just joshing me and this is a joke?

meaning: To get really angry with someone and express that emotion, perhaps in an aggressive way.
example: Why are you jumping down my throat like that! There's no need to be so defensive or upset.

meaning: To do what everyone else is doing, or to follow a trend.
example: Alan tried to give the impression that he really enjoyed his trendy new hobby, but I think he was just jumping on the bandwagon.

meaning: To start too quickly, either without adequate preparation or at the wrong time.
example: Too late, I realized that I had really jumped the gun with submitting my application. I should have spent more time on my resume.

meaning: To do things that don't seem to make much sense (or be strictly necessary), just because they're required
example: You're required to jump through a lot of hoops in order to get your professional license.

meaning: Unhealthy, usually heavily processed food (such as candy).
example: Andrea made a resolution to stop eating so much junk food. She was determined to improve her health

meaning: A decision hasn't been made yet.
example: I've asked my friends what they think I should do about my situation, but no one has answered yet. It seems that the jury is still out.

meaning: Please wait a moment or two.
example: Yes, I can put you through to his extension. Just a moment, please.

meaning: Very close by.
example: Don't worry, the store is close enough to walk to. Just around the corner.

meaning: Something has recently occurred, perhaps within the last few seconds or minutes.
example: Oh, I wish you'd come earlier! He was here just now but left really quickly.

meaning: To earn enough money to stay alive.
example: It's not the best of jobs, but it's enough to live on and keep body and soul together.

meaning: To control a situation.
example: Don’t worry about the problem. We'll keep it under control.

meaning: To keep something a secret.
example: Please keep this under wraps until I decide how to handle the situation.

idiom: Keep me posted/Keep me in the loop
meaning: To keep in contact and/or to consistently let someone know what you're doing and/or where you are.
example: I asked my friend to keep me in the loop about what she's doing this weekend. She promised she'd keep me posted

meaning: To stay calm.
example: I managed to keep my cool even when everyone criticized me for no reason.

meaning: To manage to survive adversity, especially with regard to finances.
example: They're having some financial difficulties, but they're managing to keep their heads above water. Though they're paying their bills, they aren’t able to save very much, if anything.

idiom: Keep my nose to the grindstone
meaning: To remain focused on hard work.
example: I'm going to keep my nose to the grindstone today. I've got lots of work to do.

meaning: To keep someone at a distance.
example: I'd recommend keeping them at arm's length. I'm not sure if they're trustworthy and I think you should keep your distance.

meaning: To keep something at a distance.
example: Oliver was hoping that his healthy diet would keep the flu at bay like it usually did, but this year his plan failed.

meaning: To keep something private or secret.
example: Please just keep it under your hat for now. I don't want anyone else to know.

meaning: To keep something going or to make sure it continues.
example: Could you please keep the ball rolling on this project for me while I'm away on vacation? If you could, I'd appreciate it!

meaning: To match someone else in terms of progress or success.
example: Moira was careful to try to keep up with her co-workers’ achievements.

meaning: To keep someone notified of what is happening.
example: I'll keep you posted on what happens with the situation.

meaning: To keep a positive and optimistic frame of mind.
example: I know things have been difficult lately but you've got to keep your chin up! Things will get better soon.

meaning: Maintain your sense of logic and be sensible.
example: I told her it's essential that she keep her head when dealing with all this stress. It will be difficult, but it's necessary.

meaning: Stay quiet about something.
example: I need you to keep your mouth shut about this situation. Don't tell anyone about it.

meaning: Behave well and stay out of trouble.
example: From now on, you need to stay out of trouble. Keep your nose clean.

meaning: Stay aware of the situation you are in and be ready to react if you need to.
example: I advised them to keep their wits about them when walking through that area. It can be quite dangerous.

meaning: To try to keep up with other people in terms of wealth and material possessions.
example: I feel sorry for that family. They spent so much money just trying to keep up with the Joneses, and now they're in a lot of debt. How silly of them to think that they needed to copy their neighbor and have three sports cars!

meaning: To be kept unaware of something.
example: They kept me in the dark about their real plans for the trip. I thought that was very unfair, as I deserved to know the details.

meaning: To be tense and anxious, perhaps in anticipation of something.
example: Justin was a bit keyed up yesterday. He has an interview coming up soon, and he really needs this job.

meaning: Celebrate.
example: Mia and Ava decided they would have a good time this weekend. They wanted to celebrate, really kick up their heels!

meaning: To do something that ruins someone else’s mood.
example: We were having a fun time at the party until Margaret arrived. She really killed the mood

idiom: Kill two birds with one stone
meaning: To accomplish two tasks with one action.
example: Elizabeth decided to run another errand while she was in the area. By doing so, she killed two birds with one stone.

meaning: Everything, or all things, involved in something.
example: Wow! You packed a lot of luggage for this trip. You seem to have packed the whole kit and caboodle!

meaning: An automatic, unthinking reaction.
example: I wish Walter would think more about how he responds to things. He always seems to give a knee-jerk reaction.

meaning: Extremely young and small.
example: My grandfather said he was knee-high to a grasshopper when he started to learn how to ride a bike.

meaning: Something that is made useless or debunked.
example: The scientist knocked their theory into a cocked hat. He totally disproved it

meaning: Stop it.
example: Knock it off! You're being too silly.

meaning: To tap your knuckle on wood in an effort to avoid bad luck.
example: I hope the roof stays okay for the remainder of the winter. Knock on wood!

meaning: To surprise and impress someone.
example: Your presentation knocked our socks off! Everyone was talking about it afterward.

meaning: To have a detailed understanding of something.
example: It didn't take long to train her. She seemed to know all the ins and outs of the job within a couple of weeks

meaning: To understand what to do and how to do it.
example: They made sure the new hire was trained by someone who really knew the ropes in the department.

idiom: Know which way the wind is blowing
meaning: To comprehend a situation (generally negative).
example: I was thinking about applying to work at that company, but I wanted to wait and see which way the wind was blowing. It seems to be in trouble.

meaning: To be extremely knowledgeable on a topic.
example: He's an expert on this topic. Without question, he knows his onions!

meaning: To know nothing.
example: He knows zip on the subject. There's no need to consider his opinion.

meaning: To give in or be defeated.
example: Unfortunately, Ryan ended up knuckling under with all the pressure. He gave in before the contest was even over.

meaning: Something one loves to do, especially for the benefit of someone one loves.
example: Don't worry about all the time I spent knitting this sweater. It was a labor of love.

meaning: To lose one's job.
example: James found out that he is getting laid off from his job. He's really worried, as he won't have an income and will have to look for a new position.

meaning: To be in an extremely luxurious situation.
example: The Smith family is extremely wealthy and lives in the lap of luxury. They have a mansion and two summer homes.

meaning: Something that is saved for last, but is not necessarily less important than whatever has come before it.
example: We're having a delicious dinner tonight. And, last but not least, we're going to enjoy some lovely ice cream.

meaning: The latest problem in a series of problems. Something that leads someone to finally lose their patience.
example: Mr. Johnson said that Tom's sloppy work this past week was the last straw. He was going to be fired.

meaning: A final, perhaps desperate, effort at something.
example: He decided to make a last-ditch effort to fix the web site. He didn't know if he'd be successful, but he was going to give it his best shot.

idiom: Laugh all the way to the bank
meaning: To gain money, most likely in a dishonest manner, and to feel smug about it.
example: No wonder the owner of that fraudulent company is so happy. He must be laughing all the way to the bank.

meaning: To do something that is embarrassing.
example: I'm afraid I'll lay an egg during the play tomorrow. I just hope I get my lines right.

meaning: To set rules, probably strict ones.
example: The parents decided they needed to lay down the law when their kids misbehaved too badly.

idiom: Lead someone around by the nose
meaning: To compel someone to do something, especially through manipulation or bullying.
example: We don't like the way that she leads all her friends around by the nose. She's always bossing them around and telling them what to do.

meaning: To memorize something.
example: In the past, students tended to have to learn most things by rote.

meaning: To learn how to do something—especially, to learn how to do well in a new job
example: It will take a while for the new trainees to learn the ropes and become full employees.

meaning: To have learned from an experience, probably one caused by a mistake.
example: Noah learned his lesson about planning ahead when he ran out of time to study for his test.

meaning: I want to be alone, so please stop talking to me; please go somewhere else, somewhere out of my sight.
example: Look, please just leave me alone. I don't want to talk about this right now.

meaning: To look in every possible place.
example: I promise that I'll leave no stone unturned while looking for that book you want.

meaning: To leave someone in a difficult position and to take things away from them.
example: They left him high and dry. It was extremely unfair for them to treat him like that.

meaning: Don’t involve yourself in a situation that already seems stable and decent enough.
example: Don’t bother her with that tonight. Leave well enough alone.

meaning: To be left in a difficult situation.
example: I was left in the lurch by my co-workers the other day. They left the entire remainder of the work to me.

meaning: Left out of something pleasant, or excluded from an opportunity.
example: He wanted to invest in the endeavor but was left out in the cold. He couldn't find the opportunity.

meaning: To leave someone somewhere and to go somewhere else.
example: The group of teenagers acted unpleasantly toward their friend. They even left her behind when they decided to go downtown.

meaning: Please listen to me.
example: If you'd lend me your ear for a few moments, I'd like to play my newest song for you.

meaning: To help someone.
example: Lauren gave Debbie a hand with her homework. She often helped her in this way.

meaning: Leave past grievances in the past.
example: James and Jonathan had argued a lot in the past, but they decided to let bygones be bygones and to focus on the future.

meaning: Stop talking about an issue.
example: Jessica told me that she still wants to try to address the issue with Molly. But I said it might be better to let sleeping dogs lie

meaning: To refrain from holding someone accountable for something.
example: He was angry that his friend was late returning his book, but he let him off the hook.

idiom: Let the cat out of the bag
meaning: To reveal a secret.
example: The release date for the book remained a secret for a long time, but someone finally let the cat out of the bag

meaning: To wait for circumstances to return to normal after something significant has happened.
example: Brad's family has just had a major crisis and they're still recovering. I told him to try to wait for the dust to settle before he makes any major decisions.

meaning: Let yourself relax.
example: Don't worry about all the things you need to do tomorrow. Just let your hair down and enjoy yourself.

meaning: Precisely correct.
example: Everything she does is letter perfect. She's a great student and does wonderfully on her tests.

meaning: Fair and even circumstances, especially when it comes to anything with an element of competition.
example: I feel that there should be a level playing field in school. Teachers and others should make an effort to ensure that all students have the things they need to succeed.

meaning: A very comfortable, and probably luxurious, life.
example: They won the lottery last year. That's why they can live the life of Riley now.

meaning: Someone you love who makes your life more cheerful and that you like to be around.
example: Brenda said that her daughter is the light of her life. She is always talking about her.

idiom: Like a chicken with its head cut off
meaning: To behave in a frenzied manner
example: Marcie acted like a chicken with its head cut off when she heard the news. She got really anxious and ran around in a panic!

meaning: To have a stunned or confused look on one's face.
example: He looked like a deer in headlights when they confronted him about the money.

meaning: On a very regular basis.
example: The event happened every other Friday night, like clockwork.

idiom: Like nailing jello to the wall
meaning: A very difficult or impossible task.
example: Figuring out what we should do was really difficult. It was like nailing jello to the wall.

meaning: Extremely difficult; often refers to a difficulty in getting someone to do something
example: Trying to make the store manager realize that I deserved a refund was like pulling teeth. I was there for half an hour!

meaning: Something you never forget, or stop knowing, how to do.
example: She was worried that she wouldn't remember how to solve the problem. However, she soon realized that it was a bit like riding a bike. You never forget.

idiom: Like taking candy from a baby
meaning: Extremely easy to do, especially something that involves convincing someone to do, or to give, something.
example: Convincing Paul to give me the information I needed was easy. It was like taking candy from a baby.

meaning: Living in the moment.
example: They went from store to store yesterday, shopping as if there was no tomorrow.

idiom: Like water off a duck's back
meaning: It doesn't bother me.
example: The other students thought they were bothering me with their teasing. They didn't realize it was like water off a duck's back.

meaning: I will learn from a mistake that I have made.
example: I made a huge mistake the other day. But live and learn.

meaning: To be non-judgmental of others.
example: I believe in everyone living the way that they feel is best for them. Live and let live!

meaning: Have lots of fun.
example: I think it's time to live it up this weekend. We've been working so hard.

meaning: Living a wonderful life, the type one would dream of
example: I asked how they felt after they won the lottery. They said they're living the dream!

meaning: Absolutely everything involved.
example: Can you believe it? They thought they were going to take everything, lock, stock, and barrel!

meaning: A sad facial expression.
example: Why the long face? I thought you felt happy now.

meaning: Older or elderly.
example: Bill has been feeling a bit long in the tooth lately. He thinks he's old now.

meaning: I haven't seen you in a long time.
example: Long time no see! I think we last saw each other a couple of years ago.

meaning: Think carefully before acting or taking a risk.
example: Look before you leap! You don't want to leave your job for a new one without first thinking it out properly.

meaning: To look very attractive, usually welldressed.
example: Tricia took three hours to get ready for the dance. Her family told her she looked like a million bucks!

idiom: Look like the cat that swallowed the canary/got the cream
meaning: To look smugly pleased or satisfied with oneself.
example: Kathryn was so pleased with herself. She looked like the cat that swallowed the canary!

meaning: A person who is unpredictable and difficult to control, and who will probably inadvertently cause problems.
example: Everyone in the office thought that David was a loose cannon. He was extremely unpredictable and seemed likely to cause problems.

meaning: To lose a large amount of money, probably one’s financial security as a whole.
example: The businesspeople ended up losing their shirt on the new venture. It was a disaster.

meaning: To discontinue contact with someone, often unintentionally.
example: The two friends lost touch over the years. They no longer exchanged letters or holiday cards.

meaning: To go crazy.
example: He was quite rude about his friend. He said that he thought that he'd lost his marbles and couldn’t think rationally anymore.

meaning: To lose one’s ability or skill in a specific area.
example: I was worried that I might have lost my touch when I failed to convince my friend of something the other day. I've always been so good at persuading people.

meaning: To feel confused about a situation, and to not know what to do.
example: He said he feels lost at sea right now. He can't decide what path to take.

meaning: To become overcome with emotion or anger; to act irrationally.
example: I'm afraid I lost my head the other day when I found out about my friend's betrayal. The news shocked me.

meaning: Something that is easy to take advantage of.
example: It turned out that they saw me as low-hanging fruit. They thought they could take advantage of my kindness.

meaning: To be very lucky.
example: She lucked out when she won $1,000 on a scratch card.

meaning: Something very lucky has happened.
example: The actress got a lucky break when she found a way to get to the audition and then won the part.

meaning: A lucky person.
example: You lucky dog! I can't believe you won that sports car!

meaning: Crazy or frantic.
example: He's as mad as a hornet! Did you see the way he was acting? It was crazy.

meaning: When a couple is extremely well-suited to each other.
example: The couple has so much in common that people say they are made for each other.

idiom: Made my hair stand on end
meaning: To be very frightened.
example: The horror movie was terrifying! It made my hair stand on end.

meaning: To go directly toward.
example: Whenever his friend comes over, he always makes a beeline for his video game system! They enjoy playing together.

meaning: To complain loudly
example: The customer made a big stink when he complained about the bad quality of the product.

meaning: To recount something in a brief way, leaving out unnecessary details.
example: Yes, we plan to go there again. To make a long story short, we had an amazing time!

idiom: Make a mountain out of a molehill
meaning: To exaggerate about the significance or severity of circumstances.
example: Sabrina was really overreacting. She was making a mountain out of a molehill.

meaning: To stop somewhere for a short period of time, usually during a long journey.
example: We made a lot of pit stops on the road trip, to go to the bathroom and to eat.

meaning: To create a fuss of some kind that draws the attention of others in a negative way.
example: Stop talking so loudly! I know you're upset, but you are making a scene. People are looking.

meaning: To have enough money for daily expenses over the course of a month.
example: Kim was finding it difficult to make ends meet because of her limited income.

meaning: To look at someone in a flirtatious way.
example: She was making eyes at the guy she had a crush on all evening

idiom: Make hay while the sun shines
meaning: To make full use of a good situation.
example: We considered putting off taking advantage of the situation. After a while, though, we realized that we should make hay while the sun was still shining.

meaning: To say something in a very definite way that doesn't allow for objections.
example: Diane made no bones about how she felt. She described it very clearly and no one was about to argue with her.

meaning: To have success in a venture, especially one involving money or other benefits.
example: Ethan was an amazing negotiator. It seemed like he was always making out like a bandit in business deals.

meaning: Discern what someone said.
example: She was at the other end of the room and I couldn't make out what she said; she spoke too softly for me to hear.

meaning: To be satisfactory or to meet necessary standards.
example: Lara said she didn't end up making the grade in her evaluation the other day. Her work isn't up to standard, so she has to improve.

meaning: To promptly or quickly leave.
example: I think it's time we made tracks. I have an appointment this afternoon and if I don't leave now, I might be late.

meaning: To create any controversy or trouble.
example: I was thinking about expressing my disagreement on the issue, but I really want to avoid making waves right now.

meaning: An invitation to feel comfortable in someone else’s home.
example: I'll probably have to go out right after you arrive, but I want you to make yourself at home.

meaning: A dog.
example: He loves his dog. Well, you know what they say! A dog is man's best friend.

meaning: To wait out the minimum time you need to put in.
example: We got the impression that the new employee was just marking time. He didn't seem to be trying very hard, and his gaze kept focusing on the clock.

meaning: The basics of something or a situation.
example: Let's not talk about the details of the matter right now. We'll just focus on the meat and potatoes.

meaning: To understand one another's positions in an argument or situation, and to make compromises accordingly.
example: I think it's time for Janet and Ellen to meet halfway on this issue. They are both right in some ways and wrong in others, and they should compromise.

meaning: A job that is considered insignificant, perhaps even useless.
example: People said I had a mickey mouse job in customer service. They thought it was unimportant and wouldn't lead to any other opportunities.

meaning: To be able to make money much more easily than other people.
example: It seems like everything she touches turns to gold; she makes so much money and doesn’t even have to try that hard. She has the Midas touch.

meaning: A position (especially political) that is not at either extreme of the spectrum. It is pretty much in the middle.
example: Ben didn't really have many opinions on politics, but he could say that the ones he had were generally middle of the road

meaning: Mind your own business and refrain from interfering in other people's concerns.
example: Why are you asking me all of these questions? It's my private business. Mind your own beeswax!

meaning: To miss out on an opportunity because you're too late.
example: I don't want to miss the boat on this investment opportunity.

meaning: A small family-run business, or a tiny establishment, such as a corner shop.
example: Have you ever been to the little store around the corner? It's a real classic mom-and-pop shop.

idiom: Money burns a hole in someone's pocket
meaning: When someone feels the need to spend money simply because they have it.
example: It's hard for Tim to save money. He says that money always burns a hole in his pocket and he wants to spend it right away.

meaning: Money can be used to gain power and leverage; there is a strong implication of corruption.
example: Many people wondered how he got the contract; it didn’t seem so mysterious to me. Money talks.

meaning: To have large amounts of extra money.
example: They've apparently got money to burn. They've done a huge number of unnecessary renovations to their house, just to make it more luxurious, and they have four sports cars!

meaning: To get a lot of value for your money.
example: The saleswoman told Andrea she should go with the other TV because it would give more bang for her buck.

meaning: More than I expected.
example: The amount of work Douglas was assigned was more than he had bargained for. He felt overwhelmed.

meaning: There is more to it than you think.
example: Don't underestimate what could happen. There's a lot more than meets the eye here.

meaning: To make some adjustments.
example: Let me see if I can move some things around in my schedule so that I can book you an appointment for next week.

meaning: Meaningless words or nonsense.
example: I heard about the theory, but honestly I felt it was really a bunch of mumbo jumbo. It sounded like nonsense to me.

meaning: Stay quiet and don't talk about it.
example: I trusted you when I told you all about my secret yesterday, so please remember that mum's the word. Don’t tell anyone else about it.

meaning: It was my mistake and I take responsibility for it.
example: Sorry about that. I thought that what I said about the store I recommended was true. My bad.

idiom: My eyes are bigger than my stomach
meaning: I wanted to eat more than my stomach could handle.
example: I put way too much on my plate at the buffet. Apparently, my eyes were bigger than my stomach.

meaning: I cannot do anything to change the situation because I am not the one who can make the decision.
example: I'm sorry but I can't change the meeting time. My hands are tied; my boss is the one who makes those decisions.

meaning: It means a lot to me to do something.
example: My heart is set on going to Europe this year. I just hope it will be possible.

meaning: Where one lives.
example: Ashley couldn't find any fashionable clothing stores near her. She always complained about the limited shopping options in her neck of the woods.

meaning: Savings that are meant for use in the future.
example: They had a large nest egg. There wasn't a need to worry about their finances. They'd probably be quite wealthy when they retired.

idiom: Never bite the hand that feeds you
meaning: Don't hurt someone who helps you.
example: I don't think you should say anything potentially hurtful to him. Remember, it's best not to bite the hand that feeds you.

meaning: New person in an area, or a person newly involved in something.
example: Marie had a hard time when she first started her new job. She felt like the new kid on the block and excluded from the other employees' friendships.

meaning: A minute that seems to pass especially quickly in a hectic environment.
example: It seemed like less than a New York minute before my book was stolen! I barely had time to blink.

meaning: Someone who tends to stay up very late at night.
example: I am a bit of a night owl and tend to stay up after everyone else goes to sleep.

meaning: To prevent something from getting worse by cutting it off at the very beginning.
example: When we were kids in elementary school, our teachers always said that bad behavior needed to be nipped in the bud.

meaning: The most fundamental aspects of something. Can have a negative connotation.
example: Melvin felt awkward about talking about the subject with his co-worker, but eventually he felt the need to get down to the nitty-gritty and address it.

meaning: Not anything of significance.
example: Don't worry about the issue. It's no big deal. No need to worry.

meaning: It's not going to happen.
example: I hoped to get the time off to go to the Caribbean this year, but no dice. My vacation will have to wait.

meaning: You need to exert yourself to accomplish things.
example: You should go on morning runs to get fit. No pain, no gain!

meaning: Without explanation or logic
example: With no rhyme or reason, my friend decided to move across the country.

meaning: Easy and simple
example: It was easy for me to help Joey with his math problem. It was a no-brainer. I didn't tell him that, though! He might have been insulted.

meaning: To have no decency at all, or no manners or consideration.
example: Hannah was really upset with how her friend reacted to her crisis. She felt he didn't have a spark of decency.

idiom: Not have a leg to stand on
meaning: Lacking the ability to support an argument.
example: The competitor in the debate doesn't have a leg to stand on with his argument.

meaning: Something that doesn't fit one's taste, or that one doesn’t enjoy or like.
example: I never watch football. It's never really been my cup of tea.

idiom: Not playing with a full deck
meaning: Not very intelligent.
example: James is really difficult to work with. He doesn't seem to know what he's doing. I don't think he's playing with a full deck. He doesn't seem very smart.

idiom: Not what it's cracked up to be
meaning: Something is not as good or impressive as people have implied.
example: Yes, we went to that amusement park last summer. It's not what it's cracked up to be though. There weren't very many rides.

meaning: Something that lacks any value.
example: I wish I could sell my car, but the truth is it's not worth a red cent! Who would buy it?

meaning: Nothing exciting or extraordinary.
example: The meal at the famous restaurant was quite good, but it was nothing to write home about. It simply wasn't as special as I thought it would be.

meaning: Someone who works with numbers, especially in a tedious way, in accounting or finance.
example: The accountant knew he was much more than just a number cruncher. For that reason, he got annoyed when people called him that.

meaning: Person who doesn't fit in or who is somehow left out.
example: Nathan always felt like he was the odd man out when his friends got together. He just didn't think he really belonged.

meaning: For something to be a little odd or perhaps objectionable in some way.
example: The comedian's jokes were a little off-color. They made some people feel uncomfortable.

meaning: To start something the wrong way or in a way that is disadvantageous to you.
example: Mike got off on the wrong foot with his interview. He arrived late and was inadvertently rude to the employer about something!

meaning: To do something spontaneously, or without much preparation.
example: She made her speech completely off the cuff, without a single note to refer to. I could never do that.

meaning: To not be held responsible for something.
example: I'm so relieved. The teacher is letting me off the hook even though my homework is late. He's not marking down my grade.

meaning: To saying something that you don't want the other person to tell anyone else about.
example: Can I tell you something off the record? Peggy said that she has decided on a new career, but she isn't sure yet when she'll be handing in her notice at her current job.

idiom: Off the top of my head
meaning: Without any previous consideration.
example: Off the top of my head, I'd say that red is my favorite color. I've never really thought about it, though.

meaning: Bizarre or crazy
example: We all agreed that his reaction was totally off the wall! It didn't make any sense and defied logic.

meaning: To be old-fashioned in some way.
example: He's kind of old school. He always listens to records and he hates downloading music.

meaning: On an extremely limited budget.
example: They are going on vacation, but it's going to be on a shoestring. They don't have very much money right now.

meaning: A time of emotional reactivity, energy, or heightened emotions. Can also mean a period of drug use or drunkenness.
example: He was on a tear when we last saw him. That's how upset he was.

meaning: Stuck in a routine that is boring and dull.
example: Grace feels she's on a treadmill with her current routine. She wants to change her life but doesn't know how.

meaning: Extremely happy or blissful.
example: We've all been on cloud nine since hearing the wonderful news.

meaning: To be nervous or anxious, especially in anticipation of something.
example: She's on pins and needles about her interview tomorrow. She's very nervous.

meaning: Being alert and competent when completing a task.
example: Annabelle is definitely going to win the employee of the year award. She's so on the ball in everything she does.

meaning: Not working as it should. Usually applies to a piece of equipment.
example: The stove is on the blink! That's why we can't make any soup tonight.

meaning: For little money and/or on a limited budget.
example: I'm going, but I'm going to do it on the cheap. I don't want to spend too much money.

meaning: To get somewhere right on time.
example: I got to the appointment at 3:15 p.m. on the dot. I didn’t even have to wait for the receptionist to call my name!

meaning: Having a difficult time making a decision about something.
example: He's still on the fence about whether he should go to France or Spain.

meaning: Doing something else while on the go.
example: She just left to go to work, but she said she'd pick up a newspaper on the fly.

meaning: Something is not working as it should.
example: It was a tricky day in the office yesterday. It seemed like every piece of equipment was on the fritz! We could hardly get anything done.

meaning: Free, at the expense of the restaurant or bar.
example: The bartender gave us some drinks on the house!

meaning: Honest.
example: I truly feel that the salesperson was on the level when she claimed that this would suit my needs perfectly.

meaning: In jeopardy in some way.
example: They put all their resources on the line with the new business. It ended up being a mistake.

meaning: To think the same way.
example: We're definitely on the same page when it comes to the office party. We agree on what should be done.

meaning: Right here, at this time.
example: He made the decision on the spot; He did not need any additional time to consider the alternatives.

idiom: On the spur of the moment
meaning: Spontaneously and without prior planning.
example: I know I didn't tell you we'd be going for a country drive; we just decided to go there on the spur of the moment!

idiom: On the top of the world
meaning: Feeling very happy and perhaps triumphant.
example: My brother was feeling on the top of the world when he found out that he got his dream job.

meaning: Fair and ethical.
example: We were worried at first that the book might have been dishonest, but now we believe that it is actually on the up and up. The contents seem unbiased and well-researched.

meaning: Extremely angry and wanting to confront someone.
example: Watch out for Dan! He's extremely angry about the work you did and is on the warpath. He's such a difficult boss.

meaning: You have already made several mistakes and if you make another one, you will be in trouble.
example: My teacher told me that I'm on thin ice. If I do poorly on another assignment, I could get a failing grade.

meaning: Indicating a permanent answer or solution.
example: Once and for all, I wish you would admit that you were wrong on that subject.

meaning: Something unpleasant has happened, so now you exercise more cautious to prevent the same thing from happening again.
example: I don't think I'll shop at that store again. They ripped me off on something a few years ago. Once bitten, twice shy.

meaning: Something that very rarely happens.
example: I like ice cream, but I only have it once in a blue moon because it's unhealthy.

meaning: In one quick and sweeping effort.
example: It's true! We got all of this done in one fell swoop this morning.

meaning: Someone who is only really good at one thing.
example: Jeremy is kind of a one-trick pony. He's only good at that one thing and nothing else.

meaning: To open up discussion or contemplation of a new topic, or a new situation, probably a tricky one.
example: Hannah discouraged us from asking our friends that question. She said it would open up a whole new can of worms.

meaning: Not relevant or applicable today; if in relation to food, no longer safe to eat.
example: We told her that the skirt she wanted to buy was a bit out of date. It seemed like something that would have been fashionable many years ago.

meaning: Unrelated to the issue at hand, or whatever is being discussed.
example: Katie made a really strange comment yesterday. It didn't have anything to do with what we were talking about. It was just so out of left field!

meaning: Out of your control.
example: It's out of my hands now. There's nothing I can do to make changes to the project.

meaning: No longer working or effective; in some contexts, unacceptable.
example: Don't bother putting your money in that vending machine. It's out of order and won't give you a candy bar.

meaning: Something that occurs unexpectedly and abruptly
example: That letter really came from out of the blue! I hadn't heard from her in years!

idiom: Out of the frying pan and into the fire
