meaning: Things were bad, but now they'll get worse.
example: He thought his new job would be easier than his previous one, but it isn't. It's actually harder! Out of the frying pan and into the fire.

meaning: Not possible or acceptable.
example: It's simply out of the question for him to buy that. He can't afford it.

meaning: A difficult situation has improved or become easier to deal with. The most challenging part is over.
example: The horrible time the Maxwell family has been going through might end soon, but they're not quite out of the woods yet.

meaning: Extraordinary.
example: The celebration was out of this world. It was extraordinary and something I'll never forget.

meaning: To go out and enjoy yourself.
example: They went out on the town last night, visiting a few nightclubs and just having fun.

meaning: Confused or unaware of circumstances or reality, or perhaps absentminded.
example: I tried to talk to my professor this morning but he seemed very distracted. I've heard of professors being a little absentminded, but this guy is out to lunch!

meaning: To forbid something.
example: You think you're going there by yourself? Over my dead body! You're only twelve years old.

meaning: People in a very crowded and limited space.
example: It was a nightmare on the subway yesterday. We were packed like sardines!

meaning: Something that is causing you problems.
example: She decided to stop talking to Jack. She thought he was a pain in the neck.

meaning: To go out and enjoy a city's nightlife.
example: The group of friends are going out for drinks tonight. They said they're determined to paint the town red!

meaning: Explain something in detail.
example: I painted a picture of the situation for him by describing everything in great detail.

meaning: A situation that involves unexpected consequences and problems.
example: We considered talking about the issue, but we changed our minds when we decided that it would be like opening Pandora's box.

meaning: To be expected.
example: That was nothing out of the ordinary. It was all par for the course.

meaning: Someone who goes to parties frequently and acts wildly, perhaps binge drinking and/or being loud.
example: Some of the college students were party animals. They spent too much time drinking and not enough time studying.

meaning: To put the blame or responsibility on someone else.
example: Max felt too frustrated to call and lodge a complaint with the company. He said it would be a waste of time; they always seem to find a way to pass the buck

meaning: Did all the work necessary for a course and earned an acceptable final grade.
example: I passed the course! I'm so relieved—I needed to get a “C” or better in order to take the next math class.

meaning: Pay a lot of money for something.
example: Emily paid a pretty penny for her new living room set. It was quite expensive.

idiom: Pay an arm and a leg
meaning: To pay a huge amount of money for something.
example: He loves luxurious cars and has always wanted a Mercedes, but he realized that he'd have to pay an arm and a leg to get one.

meaning: Deal with the consequences of one's actions and pay for one’s mistakes.
example: It's time to pay the piper. You've made a lot of mistakes lately and there are going to be consequences.

meaning: To pay a large amount of money that is too much for what is gained.
example: We were excited about the idea of getting the new car until we realized that we’d have to pay through the nose to own it. It was so overpriced!

meaning: To go really fast, probably while driving a vehicle.
example: He really put the pedal to the metal, didn't he? I think he drove too fast. He was probably over the speed limit.

meaning: To die. Used humorously and never in reference to someone who has actually died, as that would be insensitive.
example: They both love to travel. There are many places they want to go before they finally peg out!

meaning: Someone who works in an office (for example, a bureaucrat) who mainly does paperwork and probably doesn't care about advancing in his or her career.
example: We aren't very concerned about his opinion. He's just a pencil pusher in the office.

meaning: To slowly fade in importance or significance.
example: The sound we heard coming from outside finally started to peter out. We hoped it would end soon.

meaning: Pay for things (such as meals or drinks) that other people have consumed, for example, in a restaurant.
example: My friend is always very generous. She always offers to pick up the tab for both us when we go out for something to eat.

meaning: To listen more closely and carefully.
example: No, you're not listening properly. Pick up your ears!

meaning: An unrealistic dream.
example: Mandy had always wanted to be famous for something. As she got older, though, she realized that her dream was just a pie in the sky.

meaning: To eat too much food in one sitting.
example: We pigged out on junk food last night while watching movies! We ate three large bags of chips, lots of chocolates, and popcorn!

meaning: Ridiculously stubborn.
example: Tom is so pigheaded! It's really frustrating to deal with him because he'll never change his mind about anything.

meaning: To be more quiet or to stop talking completely.
example: Look, you need to pipe down! You've been speaking far too loudly.

meaning: An unrealistic dream.
example: Robert loved football and wanted to play it professionally some day. As he grew older though, he came to realize that this was just a pipe dream.

meaning: Extremely dark outside.
example: The group was too nervous to go outside because it was pitch dark and they could hardly see anything.

meaning: To help with an endeavor.
example: Adam felt bad watching everyone else do all the work. He decided that he should pitch in.

meaning: To deal with things as they come.
example: We haven't decided yet whether we'll go to the beach tomorrow or go shopping. I think we'll play it by ear.

meaning: To argue for the opposite side, simply for argument's sake.
example: I didn't really believe what I said when we were debating. I was just playing devil's advocate.

meaning: To act or work in a competitive and aggressive, or even ruthless, way (especially in business or politics).
example: The businessperson really played hardball in that meeting yesterday. She was tough!

meaning: To come second to someone else in something
example: I had to play second fiddle to Jonathan in running the office.

meaning: Pretending that you don't know or understand something.
example: Stop playing dumb! I know you heard about what happened. Why are you pretending that you didn't?

meaning: To be do something or to act in a way (especially in a careless way) that could lead to a worrisome or even dangerous situation.
example: She advised me to stop challenging my boss on the matter, saying that I was probably playing with fire and that I could end up losing my job as a result.

meaning: A face without any sort of expression; others find it difficult or impossible to figure out the person's mood or thoughts.
example: Mark had an excellent poker face. If he wanted to hide it, no one could tell what he was thinking or how he felt.

meaning: To look for a job by walking the pavement, going from place to place.
example: Hannah had been looking for a job for a very long time and was trying to think of new approaches. A friend suggested just pounding the pavement for a while and seeing what she could find.

meaning: To dress in a highly professional way.
example: I always recommend power dressing when you start work in any sort of formal office. It will help get you noticed and recognized

meaning: Being too arrogant can lead to significant problems, perhaps even your downfall.
example: I tried to warn her; I told her to remember that pride comes before a fall. She wouldn't listen. I think she's just too arrogant.

meaning: Do the work needed to support oneself and fulfill one's needs.
example: Noah was a very hard worker. He always pulled his weight.

meaning: To achieve something that had seemed very difficult to do.
example: Tim's essay is due tomorrow and he hasn't even started. I don't think he'll be able to pull it off in time.

meaning: To do everything possible to accomplish a goal. This might involve sparing no expense and using every resource.
example: I decided to pull out all the stops when I bought my new outfit. I wanted to be the best-dressed person at the upcoming event.

meaning: To take advantage of the superior position that one holds.
example: Don't pull rank with me. You're not above me in this organization.

meaning: To make a joke and momentarily fool or trick someone.
example: I didn't actually go skydiving last weekend. I was just pulling your leg!

meaning: To use one's influence to make something happen that probably wouldn't have taken place otherwise.
example: It turned out that he pulled strings to get his brother the job. That's really unfair.

meaning: To end something or put a stop to it.
example: They pulled the plug on our team's project. They said they lost the funding.

idiom: Pull the wool over your eyes
meaning: When someone sets out to deceive you
example: I was frustrated and upset with Arthur for hiding the truth from me. He really pulled the wool over my eyes and now it's caused me problems

meaning: To gather up your household and move somewhere else.
example: They expected everyone to just pull up stakes and move to the other side of the country for the sake of the company. This seems very unreasonable.

meaning: To annoy you in some way, or to be unfair to you.
example: I decided to cut down on the amount of time I spent with Sydney. She was constantly pulling my chain and I couldn't relax with her.

meaning: To calm yourself and become focused again.
example: Beth was really upset after the phone call, but it didn't take long for her to pull herself together.

idiom: Pulled a rabbit out of one's hat
meaning: To do something amazing and unexpected.
example: Ruth rendered us speechless the other day. She pulled a rabbit out of her hat and found money for the trip.

idiom: Pulled the rug out from under me
meaning: Someone does or says something that makes you feel disoriented and confused about what to do next
example: The company president's announcement about job losses pulled the rug out from under me. I'm really worried now.

meaning: Joking with me or playing a joke on me.
example: I don't believe what you said about going scuba diving. You were pulling me leg, weren't you?

meaning: Love between two young and innocent people.
example: Everyone said her feelings for her first boyfriend were just puppy love.

meaning: Doing something that could cause you to get into trouble.
example: You're pushing your luck right now. You should start acting more sensibly

meaning: Be quiet; stop making noise
example: They told Paul to put a sock in it! He was being too noisy.

meaning: To rebuke someone and/or make them feel more humble.
example: Natalie put Lisa in her place for insinuating that she wasn't very smart. She asked how it could be possible that Lisa was more intelligent when she had earned better marks in every course.

idiom: Put it on the back burner
meaning: To make something a lower priority for a while.
example: I have so much to do that I think I'll need to put this task on the back burner for a while; I’ll get back to it later.

meaning: To assert one's authority about something.
example: The parents put their foot down with their son; they declared that he wasn't allowed to have any more new toys this month.

meaning: To try to think more intensely and carefully about something.
example: It's time for us to put our thinking caps on, so that we can come up with some new ideas for the class trip.

meaning: Two people share thoughts and try to come up with new ideas or a solution to something.
example: Let's put our heads together and come up with a solution to this problem.

meaning: To put someone in a tricky situation and/or to embarrass him or her.
example: It's wasn't fair for Katie to put me on the spot like she did yesterday. How was I supposed to know that she'd suddenly ask me to travel with her next week, and that she’d expect me to give her an answer right away?

idiom: Put something down in black and white
meaning: To put something in writing.
example: They were glad to have the contract. It was good to have everything in black and white.

meaning: To act on the basis of some kind of idea or principle.
example: She's all talk. Why doesn't she put any of her ideas into practice?

meaning: To put something on hold with the plan to resume it later.
example: The project was going well but other more pressing things came up, so we put it on ice.

meaning: To put intense pressure on someone to carry out a task, or to coerce or force someone to make something happen.
example: I don't like it when people unfairly put the squeeze on me. If I can't do it, I can't do it!

meaning: To properly identify and comprehend something.
example: You really put your finger on it when you said that he needs to go back to school. He won't progress in his career unless he upgrades his qualifications.

idiom: Put your money where your mouth is
meaning: To actually invest in something that you claim to believe in.
example: I think he's all talk when he describes his business plans. He needs to put his money where his mouth is.

meaning: Time spent with someone you care about.
example: The parents were worried that they weren't spending enough quality time with their kids. They decided to take them out to an amusement park that weekend, an activity that they could all enjoy together.

meaning: Thinking intensely, trying to recall or remember something.
example: I've been racking my brain for hours, but I just can't seem to remember where I left that notebook.

meaning: To ruin someone's enthusiasm for something, especially with a negative opinion.
example: I don't mean to rain on your parade, but one person on the committee didn't like your work.

meaning: No matter what.
example: Don't worry! The mail will surely be delivered, rain or shine.

meaning: Make a disturbance or a huge public conflict.
example: Zack was always really difficult. It seemed like the slightest little thing ended up with him raising Cain and making a gigantic fuss!

meaning: To exert authority over someone who is behaving in a way that is out of line.
example: They read their son the riot act when he had a huge party in the house and caused lots of damage

meaning: A genuine thing.
example: Yes, that's the real McCoy. It's definitely a genuine bottle of that perfume.

meaning: A sign that acts as a warning of some kind.
example: When I look back, I see there were quite a few red flags that should have made me reconsider my decision.

meaning: A clue that is meant to distract or mislead.
example: It took us a while to figure out that the clue was just a red herring. We had to start all over with our investigation.

meaning: Bashful or embarrassed and blushing as a result.
example: Joseph tripped on his way to the podium. That's why he was so red in the face.

meaning: A memorable day, probably a pleasant one.
example: They knew that the day of their upcoming meeting was sure to be a red letter day. They felt certain that it would go wonderfully and help progress their careers.

meaning: To rely on the prestige brought about by previous accomplishments, and not bothering to do any more.
example: The artist was accused of resting on his laurels; he did not try to create any other great achievements.

meaning: Please come in this direction.
example: I'll bring you to the correct area. Just follow me. Right this way

meaning: Recognition of something.
example: Someone I recently met said they know you. Her name is Deanna. Does that ring a bell?

meaning: Cheap and low-quality.
example: We thought it was a rinky-dink sort of bike. It didn’t even come with a basket!.

meaning: To welcome someone (usually a prominent person or celebrity) in a very grand way.
example: The red carpet was rolled out for all the celebrities when they arrived at the awards ceremony.

meaning: Very wealthy.
example: That family owns property on every continent. They're rolling in it.

idiom: Rome wasn't built in a day
meaning: You can't accomplish a big task in too short a period of time.
example: I felt bad about not finishing the project in time, but then my friends reminded me that Rome wasn't built in a day.

meaning: To socially interact with someone who has prestige and a higher social position.
example: We were really excited about the party. We expected to rub elbows with lots of prominent people.

meaning: To cause annoyance or irritation
example: The article was very entertaining, but it certainly ruffled some feathers.

meaning: A general rule or convention.
example: The teacher told her students that it was a good rule of thumb to regularly wash the chalkboard.

meaning: To behave in a very disorderly or frenzied manner.
example: They were really ran amok last night outside. They made so much noise that the neighbors called the police!

meaning: To be more knowledgeable or skilled than someone, and to make them confused and unable to keep up as a consequence.
example: They ran circles around the other students in their knowledge of math. They were incredibly skilled for their age.

meaning: To go out and do things you need to do.
example: I've got to run some errands this morning. They're all really important, but quite boring.

meaning: To let something proceed as it would without intervention.
example: We think that the best thing would be to let the situation run its course. Intervening wouldn't really accomplish anything.

meaning: To run really quickly
example: I'm determined to run like the wind during the next track and field meet.

meaning: Common and ordinary.
example: I liked the sweater that Amy pointed out, but I honestly felt that it was a bit run-of-the-mill. I could probably find one like it anywhere.

meaning: To speak too much on something that you shouldn't.
example: I don't want to run my mouth off, but I don't think you should go there tomorrow—and here's why.

meaning: To run out of energy.
example: I tried to finish rearranging the furniture yesterday, but I ran out of steam and had to get some sleep.

meaning: To be in charge of somethin
example: The manager was determined to run the show in his office.

meaning: To stay awake even when you're exhausted.
example: The student had stayed up for hours studying and felt like he needed to go to sleep soon. He was running on fumes.

meaning: To push boundaries or act in a way that is just within the limits of social and legal acceptability.
example: Jacob decided that one of his employees had been sailing close to the wind with how much she had been slacking off. He thought he might have to fire her.

meaning: A presentation or speech made in an attempt to persuade someone to purchase a product.
example: His sales pitches were pretty weak. I don't think they'd convince anyone to buy anything. He probably shouldn't dream of a career as a salesperson.

meaning: To be highly moral and honest.
example: The people of the village were really the salt of the earth. They were so very good and modest.

meaning: To get somewhere at the last possible moment.
example: I was almost late for class yesterday morning but was saved by the bell! I sat down in my seat just as the clock struck ten.

meaning: Saved someone from having to deal with some kind of disaster.
example: Erin saved my skin. She got me out of a lot of trouble.

meaning: To save money, especially keeping in mind that you might need it to address any future difficulties
example: He won $500 in a contest, but he's not spending the money. He's going to save it for a rainy day.

meaning: To admit that you have been defeated
example: I know you're too out of breath to race me again. If you insist, I bet you'll say uncle before we're done!

meaning: Say what you want to say; give your opinion.
example: Okay, I have some time to listen to you now. Go ahead and say your piece.

meaning: Someone who is blamed for things that they're not actually responsible for.
example: They weren't very nice to her. They seemed to make her the scapegoat all the time, blaming her for everything they did wrong

meaning: To frighten someone.
example: The haunted house ride scared the pants off everyone who went on it.

meaning: A way of thinking, especially with regard to an academic subject.
example: The professor explained that he belonged to a different school of thought on the subject than many other academics.

meaning: To make someone more informed in an area.
example: Chloe really schooled her brother in manners yesterday! She told him that he's rude and needs to shape up.

meaning: To get away with something without facing any consequences.
example: Everyone was very surprised and disappointed to see them get off scot-free; their actions had hurt a lot of people.

meaning: To make a mistake.
example: We screwed up on the project. That's why we got a failing grade.

meaning: Having sea legs means to maintain your balance and not get sea sickness on a ship, but it can also refer to someone becoming good at a job or task without feeling overwhelmed or lacking confidence.
example: It took quite a while for me to get my sea legs on this job.

meaning: Of a lower quality or standard.
example: Noah got upset when people said that he was a second-rate actor.

meaning: Something that makes you feel safe and secure.
example: Elise realized that she was using certain things as a security blanket. They made her feel safe and secure, but they were holding her back. She decided to try to be more confident.

meaning: To perceive and think about something in the same way as someone else.
example: After Ava and Emily discussed it for a while, they finally came to an agreement. Now they see eye to eye on the issue.

meaning: To see a person's real character.
example: I used to think that Ethan was a nice guy, but after knowing him for a while I saw his true colors. He's selfish and can be rude sometimes.

idiom: See the big picture/look at the big picture
meaning: To understand the larger context
example: Don't worry about all the little things right now. Try to focus on the big picture.

meaning: To finally recognize the truth or reality of something.
example: A few weeks passed before we were able to make Mandy see the light about her boyfriend. Now she realizes that he is a bit of a jerk.

meaning: To have the perceptiveness needed to not be fooled by a disguise or false appearance of some kind.
example: Judy is always trying to give the impression that she is much more successful than I am, but I see through her. She exaggerates and is not as successful as she seems.

meaning: To sell extremely quickly.
example: The copies of his new book sold like hotcakes! They almost sold out the very first day.

meaning: To underestimate someone, especially their capabilities or potential.
example: You shouldn't sell him short. He's much more talented than you think

meaning: Something makes you feel extremely annoyed, perhaps to the point that you almost lose your patience or temper.
example: No, I didn't like the movie last night. The actors set my teeth on edge with their cartoonish expressions.

meaning: Move more quickly and hurry, especially in the context of getting ready to go somewhere or do something.
example: We'd better start shaking a leg! I just checked the time and it's much later than I thought. If we don't leave soon, we'll be late for the appointment.

meaning: Do better or leave.
example: Ron hasn't been doing very well at his job. His boss told him he needs to shape up or ship out.

meaning: Very clever and quick-thinking.
example: Melissa is sharp as a tack. She always knows the answers to every question in class.

meaning: Two individuals who meet and perhaps spend time together for a very brief period of time; especially used in a romantic context.
example: The love story was about two people who were like ships passing in the night. They were only able to spend a few hours together before they went their separate ways.

meaning: A very limited budget.
example: It was hard to organize the formal event on a shoestring budget.

meaning: To say something in a very direct and honest way.
example: My best friend, Anna, is really honest and direct. She likes to shoot from the hip on most occasions.

meaning: To play basketball, usually in an unstructured way.
example: The kids were outside, shooting hoops in the driveway with my basketball.

meaning: To speak in an unwarranted or offensive way.
example: No need to shoot off your mouth like that! I don't think it's necessary to be so aggressive.

meaning: To chat in a friendly and inconsequential way
example: We had a good time at lunch. We spent our time shooting the breeze and showing each other pictures of our pets!

meaning: Something that suddenly energizes someone or renews their interest in, or concern about, something.
example: Learning about their expenses last month was definitely a shot in the arm. They realized they'd been spending too much and needed to make some changes.

meaning: To make a guess based on limited information.
example: She asked me to guess where she was going this weekend, so I took a shot in the dark and said New York. I was wrong. It was San Francisco.

meaning: To ask people to raise their hand if they are present or if they agree on something.
example: The teacher wanted to know how many students agreed with the argument, so she asked for a show of hands.

meaning: To be extremely ill with a cold or the flu
example: I missed classes last week because I was as sick as a dog. I had a terrible bout of the flu.

meaning: Wait patiently, try not to worry, and don't act until you hear that you should.
example: Erin felt really anxious as she waited for the results of her university applications. But she knew she just had to sit tight and hope for the best.

idiom: Sitting like a bump on a log
meaning: Sitting around inactive, especially when other people are busy working.
example: One student sat like a bump on a log while everyone else ran around the library, looking for the books they needed.

meaning: Doing well and feeling content because of it.
example: Ethan is doing well financially. He's certainly sitting pretty with his bank account.

meaning: A sense of things or a source of perception that isn't based on any of the five senses; often refers to some sort of psychic ability or insight.
example: She must have used her sixth sense to find her friend’s missing earring; it blended completely with the pebbles on the ground.

meaning: An event or fact from someone's past that is embarrassing or disgraceful in some way and that he or she tries to keep private. This could refer to an entire family, too.
example: Mary certainly has some skeletons in the closet. There are lots of things from her past that she likes to hide.

meaning: The minimum number of people necessary for something to operate.
example: Quite a few people called in sick today. We're running the shop with a skeleton crew.

meaning: To not go to a class that you're supposed to attend.
example: The kids got in trouble with their parents when it was revealed that they had been skipping class.

meaning: A very minor punishment, usually too minor for the crime or offence.
example: I didn't think the punishment was severe enough for what he did. It was a mere slap on the wrist.

meaning: To sleep very soundly.
example: I slept like a log last night. It had been a really tiring day and I needed my rest.

meaning: Very unlikely to happen.
example: There's only a slim chance that you'll get that job. There's a lot of competition and your qualifications aren't the best.

meaning: To say something you didn't mean to say.
example: I'm sorry I said that. I didn't mean to! It was a slip of the tongue.

idiom: Slow and steady wins the race
meaning: In the end, being persistent is more important than having speed.
example: She felt bad that she wasn't as good at sports as some of her classmates, but she decided that she should keep trying. Slow and steady wins the race.

meaning: A statement expressing the idea that the world seems so small when you discover that you have mutual connections with others.
example: It's such a small world! I found out that Mary knows my old friend, Jill, from across the country.

meaning: To have the intuition that someone or something isn't quite right.
example: I think I smell a rat. I'm sure that Daniel is up to something that he shouldn't be.

meaning: The use of illusion.
example: Don't believe everything Mary says about her lifestyle. A lot of it is just smoke and mirrors. She likes to impress people.

meaning: To smoke too many cigarettes.
example: The elderly man had a lot of health problems, mainly because he'd smoked like a chimney since his youth.

meaning: Busy or overwhelmed with tasks.
example: He wanted to take part in a fun day with his friends but he was snowed under with work.

meaning: Things have gone well so far.
example: Luke is happy about how things are going at his new job. So far so good.

meaning: To tell someone's secret without permission or to report something they did.
example: Annabelle was extremely upset with her friend for telling her secret. She couldn't believe that she'd sold her out.

meaning: Something hurts or adversely affects you.
example: Amy had a terrible headache yesterday. Several times, she said that her head was killing her.

meaning: Something is terrible or disappointing.
example: The movie I saw last night sucked. Don't go to see it.

meaning: An accomplishment that you are proud of and that you can boast about.
example: I don't like to boast, but I do think my accomplishments at work this year have given me a little something to crow about.

meaning: When someone criticizes someone or something because they are jealous of them.
example: Jim complained that Jonathan cheated in the race, but there was no evidence of it and everyone said it must just be sour grapes.

meaning: Someone whom you (or someone else) just spoke about suddenly appears.
example: Have you spoken to Andy lately? Oh, speak of the devil! He's right over there.

meaning: To make something more exciting or interesting
example: They have always served the same kinds of things at their dinner parties, so they decided to spice things up and try something new.

meaning: To reveal a secret.
example: I don't understand why Rebecca won't tell me what's going on. Why won't she just spill the beans?

meaning: Someone who manipulates the communication of information to give a desired impression.
example: The politician had lots of spin doctors working for him, to help maintain the image he wished to convey.

meaning: To lack courage.
example: Everyone exclaimed that the leader was spineless when he refused to do what was needed to ensure success. He didn't have the necessary courage.

meaning: To look just like someone else.
example: We thought that Louise was the spitting image of her favorite actress.

meaning: To engage in an argument about an insignificant detail.
example: It was always so tiresome to debate anything with Melissa. She was always splitting hairs, focusing on things that didn’t matter.

meaning: To have too many responsibilities or tasks at once, and to therefore be unable to properly focus on any of them.
example: Do you know what the problem was? I was spread too thin. That's why I couldn't fully focus on the project.

meaning: A meal that includes all the food groups, to ensure health.
example: Norah was feeling very hungry. She'd only had snacks throughout the day and felt like it had been ages since she'd had a square meal.

meaning: Extremely clean.
example: Don't worry about the floor. It's squeaky clean.

meaning: To betray someone.
example: Molly told me she was very upset the other day. She'd just found out that her best friend had stabbed her in the back by spreading rumors about her.

meaning: To be firm in defending yourself, your interests, and/or your opinions.
example: She was always trying to dismiss my opinions, but this time I decided to stand my ground and to try to persuade her that I was right.

meaning: To keep in regular contact.
example: I'll miss you while you're away. Make sure to stay in touch.

meaning: To maintain costs within the limits of the budget.
example: We have to make sure that we stay on budget with this venture. We can't afford to do otherwise

meaning: To steal credit for something or to take attention away from someone else.
example: Her sister had just announced her excellent exam marks to their parents, so Alexis decided to wait a few days before sharing her own good news. She didn't want to steal her sister's thunder.

meaning: To start to do better at a task.
example: Danny decided he really needed to step up his game at school. He wasn't doing very well.

meaning: To feel annoyed, frustrated, or upset and unable to do anything about it.
example: Joe and Melinda got into an argument. Melinda felt that she was in the right and left Joe to stew in his own juices; she refused to talk to him.

idiom: Stick out like a sore thumb
meaning: To not fit in within a specific group or context.
example: No matter how hard I tried, I never seemed to fit in at their parties. I always stood out like a sore thumb.

meaning: To retain your position on something in spite of what others say.
example: I think you need to follow your own ideas and stick to your guns in this situation.

meaning: Areas of contention.
example: There were many sticking points in our discussion. That's why it was difficult for us to reach a final agreement.

meaning: Old-fashioned and inflexible.
example: Mr. Robinson is extremely old-fashioned. He's definitely a stick-in-themud.

meaning: The propensity to steal.
example: They didn't trust him to deal with money because he was known to have sticky fingers. He's a thief.

meaning: To stop accurately and promptly
example: Marie was an amazing driver. She almost got into an accident once because of someone else's carelessness, but she was able to stop on a dime and avoid it

meaning: To understand the dangers and realities of the streets (especially in more questionable areas) and to act in a cautious manner.
example: They raised their kids to be street-smart and to know how to avoid getting into dangerous situations.

meaning: To say something that might be partially true but that also has elements of exaggeration in it.
example: Laura stretched the truth when she told us about her new job. She exaggerated quite a bit about her responsibilities.

meaning: To suddenly gain a large amount of money and become wealthy.
example: During our history course, we learned about an historical figure who struck it rich during the gold rush of the nineteenth century.

meaning: To give someone the false impression that something is going to happen.
example: Don't string them along. If it's not going to happen, you need to tell them.

meaning: A person who is pompous and frustrating to deal with.
example: The businessman was a stuffed shirt. He was conceited and also didn't seem to know what he was talking about.

meaning: To accept and endure something you find humiliating in some way.
example: I think it's time for you to swallow your pride and accept that job. I know it wasn't what you wanted, but it's better than nothing right now.

meaning: To work extremely hard
example: We sweated blood working on that project, so we were extremely annoyed when it was criticized.

meaning: To be extremely anxious.
example: Chris was really anxious about his upcoming math exam. He was sweating bullets about it!

meaning: To postpone something.
example: He received an invitation to meet up with some friends, but he had to take a rain check because he was busy with work.

meaning: To instantly like someone or something.
example: The teacher took a shine to her new group of students. They all seemed to enthusiastic and polite, and she really liked them.

meaning: Relax and take care of yourself, or good-bye.
example: You need to start taking it easy. Your health is suffering because you don't relax enough.

idiom: Take it with a grain of salt/a pinch of salt
meaning: Don’t assume that something must be true.
example: My friend, who is very competitive, told me all about her recent vacation. She said it was incredibly luxurious. I took her story with a grain of salt.

meaning: To believe what someone says without verification or proof.
example: They took the man at his word when he said that the store was closing.

meaning: To overwhelm something or someone.
example: The new play took the city by storm. Everyone loved it, making it wildly successful.

meaning: To accept some sort of trouble or difficulty, and adjust to it as needed.
example: Joseph was a relaxed guy who tended to take things in stride. Whenever a difficulty arose, he stayed calm and figured out how to deal with it.

meaning: Amazing (probably in a negative way).
example: Tim told you that I said I didn't want to play in the game. Well, that really takes the cake! He's the one who pressured me not to participate.

meaning: To become the center of focus in a room; it usually involves public speaking of some kind.
example: The main speaker will take the floor at 6 p.m.

meaning: To decide to proceed with something, suddenly and perhaps with apprehension.
example: We weren't sure whether we should make the purchase, but we decided to take the plunge anyway.

idiom: Take the wind out of your sails
meaning: Feeling of disappointment.
example: Missing out on the trip really took the wind out of my sails.

meaning: Taken advantage of in some way.
example: My friend lied to me and took advantage of my kindness several times. He really took me for a ride.

meaning: To talk quickly and for a long time.
example: The presenter talked a blue streak! He talked so quickly we could barely tell when one sentence ended and a new one began. And his speech seemed to last for hours!

meaning: Someone or something a large number of people are talking (probably gossiping) about.
example: The new movie is the talk of the town everywhere.

meaning: To talk to someone excessively, especially about something insignificant.
example: They talked my ear off this morning. It seemed like they would never stop!

meaning: To speak ignorantly or foolishly.
example: I think Kim is just speaking through her hat. What she's saying couldn't be true. I don't think she's deliberately lying, but she's certainly being foolish.

idiom: Talk to someone like a Dutch uncle
meaning: To speak to someone as if they are a close relative, offering (perhaps stern) advice.
example: My math teacher talked to me like a Dutch uncle today. He gave me study tips and told me I had to start trying harder if I wanted to do well.

meaning: Don't talk to me because I'm not listening (often done while holding up the palm of one's hand).
example: You want to know what I said to Ken when he spoke to me the other day? I said just one thing: talk to the hand!

meaning: To talk in a serious way, most often with regard to a business deal.
example: The two businesspeople were at dinner, talking turkey about a possible business deal.

meaning: Talking about one's trade or occupation with another person in the same trade or occupation.
example: Two electricians were talking shop in the corner of the café.

meaning: Something that is difficult to do or achieve.
example: Wow! Well, I'll try to do what you’re asking but it's a tall order.

meaning: An unlikely story
example: The kid tells a lot of tall stories that are full of exaggerations and even lies.

idiom: Tar someone with the same brush
meaning: To assume or say that someone has the same bad characteristics as someone else, probably in the same group.
example: They always assumed that because Zoe was friends with some people who got in trouble at school, that she must be bad, too. But she wasn't. They were just tarring her with the same brush.

meaning: I already know and/or agree.
example: Tell me about it! I couldn't agree more with what you said about James being annoyed with Jonathan.

meaning: To test a situation in some way.
example: He decided to test the waters a bit before trying to resume his friendship with Mark.

meaning: That was exactly what was desired or needed, especially with regard to food or drink.
example: I find a bowl of hot chicken soup always hits the spot on a winter evening.

meaning: What I mean is.
example: She doesn't eat very much. That is to say, she has a very small appetite.

meaning: You have missed an opportunity
example: No, I'm afraid they're no longer taking applications for the job. Unfortunately, that ship has sailed.

meaning: That is all the person in question has to say about something.
example: I'm telling you the truth. I've given you all the information that Maxine gave me. That's all she wrote!

meaning: This last circumstance/occurrence has caused me to lose patience/give up.
example: I've had enough of all this. That was the last straw!

meaning: That's cool, neat, trendy, or impressive. (It depends on the context of the sentence, as wicked can also mean "evil.")
example: I just love your new sports car. It's wicked!

meaning: Someone who is cherished more than any other person.
example: Abigail's niece is the apple of her eye. She really loves her and spends lots of time with her.

idiom: The ball is in your court
meaning: It's up to you to make the next decision.
example: She decided not to contact him again; the ball was in his court now.

meaning: The best
example: My cousin is so happy with the beautiful dress she bought for the upcoming dance. She thinks it's the bee's knees!

meaning: A situation that incorporates the best elements of different things.
example: Ben loved chemistry and thought about becoming a chemist, but he also thought he'd be a good teacher. Ultimately, he became a chemistry teacher. It was the best of both worlds

idiom: The best thing since sliced bread
meaning: An excellent invention
example: They decided that the new tech gadget was the best thing since sliced bread.

meaning: New York City.
example: Are you going to the Big Apple this summer? New York City is so exciting!

meaning: New Orleans, Louisiana.
example: The Big Easy is a fascinating city. Everyone should learn about the history of New Orleans.

meaning: A company or other business's profit.
example: The CEO was worried about the company's bottom line. It wasn't doing very well.

meaning: Police officers.
example: There are many boys in blue at the festival; obviously, they’re there to keep the peace.

meaning: To dismiss someone or to be dismissed.
example: I couldn't believe it when they brushed me off. I thought they were my friends, but apparently they’re not.

meaning: The most important or significant question.
example: Sarah said that this was the burning question, but I didn't agree. I thought the other issues were more pressing.

meaning: Very nice and impressive.
example: Wow! That sports car is the cat's meow. Don't you think so?

idiom: The devil is in the details
meaning: Something might appear good when viewed from a distance. Upon closer inspection, however, problems become apparent.
example: Overall, it sounds like it would be a good contract. But remember, the devil is in the details.

idiom: The early bird gets the worm
meaning: To be ready and to get somewhere or do something early will give you the chance to reap the best results.
example: Greg thought I was crazy for getting up at five thirty in the morning every day, but I always say that the early bird gets the worm.

meaning: A huge issue that people are trying to ignore and avoid.
example: The meeting seemed to go well, with everyone giving their input on a variety of issues, but the one thing that wasn't addressed was the elephant in the room: our paychecks!

meaning: At a very late moment in some kind of situation or cycle.
example: It happened at the eleventh hour. Everyone had thought the contest was over, but then a new contestant suddenly jumped onto the stage.

meaning: The talent of speaking and getting people's attention.
example: The salesperson certainly loved to talk and was good at persuading people! Without a doubt, he had the gift of the gab.

meaning: During the final period of time available before a decision or action is required.
example: Sinead made her decision at the very last minute. Everyone was worried that she wouldn't make any kind of decision in time.

meaning: The largest portion of something.
example: Everyone was annoyed because it seemed like Brandon always got the lion's share of praise from our boss, even though we all worked equally hard.

idiom: The long and short of it
meaning: The point or the outcome.
example: It's a long story. The long and short of it, though, is that he's coming with us tomorrow. That's what really matters here.

meaning: Desire to eat, usually snacks or junk food.
example: I have the munchies! I think I'll have some pretzels.

meaning: On a day quite recently.
example: It felt like I’d seen her just the other day, but then I realized that it had been two weeks ago

meaning: To be willing to patiently deal with hardship or to generally have a lot of patience.
example: She was a wonderful teacher. She really seemed to have the patience of Job when dealing with difficult students.

meaning: A negative, disappointing circumstance or circumstances.
example: Oh, no! You're not going on the trip after all because you're sick? I'm sorry. That's really the pits!

idiom: The pot calling the kettle black
meaning: Someone with the same (or more) faults criticizing someone else.
example: Can you believe it? She actually had the nerve to criticize me for being too difficult. Talk about the pot calling the kettle black!

meaning: A path in life that most other people don't usually take.
example: People told me they couldn't understand the decision I had made. I smiled and told them I was taking the road less travelled.

meaning: To think in the same way as someone else.
example: Liz and Meg always got along very well. They seemed to be on the same wavelength about everything, and almost always agreed on various issues.

meaning: Life experience (especially difficult life experiences).
example: He explained that, while he hadn't gone to university, he had graduated from the school of hard knocks.

idiom: The shoe is on the other foot
meaning: A person is in the same situation as someone else, possibly someone whom they had judged unfairly.
example: The shoe is on the other foot now. Maybe you can finally understand what I was going through.

idiom: The short end of the stick
meaning: The lesser amount of benefit or reward, or having to do something unpleasant while other people involved do not.
example: Wow! Judith definitely got the short end of the stick when she was assigned bathroom cleaning duty.

idiom: The squeaky wheel gets the grease
meaning: You have to try to get attention if you need it. You can't just wait and hope that people will help.
example: Lily was always very assertive; she never hesitated to ask for help when she needed it. After all, she said, the squeaky wheel gets the grease.

meaning: A path of good behavior and morality.
example: She was a very cautious and moral person, always sticking to the straight and narrow course.

meaning: Things have changed.
example: That actor was once extremely popular. The tide has turned on his career though, and he no longer gets many parts in high-profile movies.

meaning: Only a tiny bit of something much larger.
example: Christopher said that this was only the tip of the iceberg; the company faced even worse problems.

meaning: To go all the way in completing a task.
example: Their employer demanded that they go the whole nine yards with every project.

idiom: There are clouds on the horizon
meaning: Trouble is going to arrive.
example: She was feeling really worried. Her friends said that everything was fine, but she was certain that there were clouds on the horizon.

idiom: There are other fish in the sea
meaning: Don't worry if you miss out on the current opportunity. There will be others. Often used with respect to a potential relationship partner.
example: Don't worry, Patricia. I know you really liked that guy, but there are other fish in the sea.

idiom: There's a method to his madness
meaning: It may seem like a person is crazy, but there are actually clever reasons behind his or her actions.
example: I know you think I'm crazy for buying so many groceries at once. But there's a method to my madness.

idiom: There's no such thing as a free lunch
meaning: Nothing in life is ever free.
example: My family often told me that there's no such thing as a free lunch. Everything comes with a price tag.

meaning: Brought together unexpectedly.
example: The friends were first thrown together when they had to team up for a project at school. They've been inseparable ever since.

meaning: To think in a unique way.
example: I think one of the reasons that she is so effective at this job is that she thinks outside the box. She's always coming up with new and unique ideas.

meaning: If you don't succeed with the first two tries, perhaps the third one will prove lucky.
example: I didn't do very well the last couple of times I played baseball. But you never know, third time's a charm!

meaning: This is a wonderful or luxurious way to live.
example: Wow, this is the life! I love staying in this luxurious resort.

idiom: Those who live in glass houses shouldn't throw stones
meaning: People with lots of faults should refrain from criticizing others.
example: Lara was always criticizing her friends for various things, but I say that people in glass houses shouldn't throw stones.

meaning: Extremely drunk.
example: Adam was three sheets to the wind on the first night of his vacation. He had way too much to drink!

meaning: Something catches you off guard and confuses you.
example: Wow! That announcement yesterday really threw me for a loop. I wasn't expecting it and I'm still feeling a bit disoriented.

meaning: In both good and bad times.
example: Janet was experiencing a stressful situation, and I was determined to help her. After all, she had stood by me through thick and thin over the years.

meaning: To abruptly present something to someone that they will have difficulty dealing with.
example: Marlene really surprised me with the news the other day. It's definitely going to affect me, too. She threw me a real curveball.

idiom: Throw a monkey wrench into the works
meaning: Doing something that causes problems for an endeavor and can cause it to fail.
example: He caused a lot of problems for our assignment the other day. What he did really threw a monkey wrench into the works.

meaning: Go ahead and task a risk.
example: I was worried about the cost of the vacation. But I decided that I could find a way to afford it and that I should throw caution to the wind

meaning: Abandoned to deal with a difficult situation.
example: The executive was thrown to the wolves when he made that mistake. No one would give him any more help.

meaning: Happy and excited.
example: My sister was tickled pink by all the wonderful things people said about her accomplishments.

meaning: To start spending less money than you used to; to be more frugal.
example: Their income is less than it used to be, so they've decided to do the wise thing and tighten their belts.

meaning: To fight in opposition of overwhelming odds—in an attempt to accomplish something good and moral—to the point of denying reality.
example: I tried to tell him that he's just tilting at windmills. Even if he works aroundthe-clock, he won’t be able to accomplish his goals.

idiom: Time flies when you're having fun
meaning: You're less likely to notice time passing when you're having a good time.
example: Is it really already five o'clock? Time flies when you're having fun!

meaning: Wasting time amounts to wasting money.
example: He decided he shouldn't go on two vacations this year. There are always many expenses to deal with, and time is money.

idiom: To be a chicken/to chicken out
meaning: To be too afraid.
example: The kids called their friends chickens for not wanting to climb on the gym equipment. They knew they were too scared.

meaning: To feel extremely emotional with worry, anxiety, or sadness.
example: My friend was just beside herself with worry about her son. He had to go to the doctor because of a health concern.

meaning: Someone who is stingy with money.
example: Mike is so closefisted! He wouldn't even contribute ten bucks for the upcoming office party.

meaning: To have a lot money; to be wealthy.
example: Tim's family never has to worry about money; they're loaded.

meaning: To be named in honor, or in memory, of someone else.
example: Melissa was named after her aunt, Melissa Smith.

idiom: To be out of the question
meaning: To be impossible or unacceptable
example: They told their kids that going to the new amusement park that weekend was out of the question. After all, they would have lots of homework to do and it would probably be rain, too.

idiom: To be tied up with something or someone
meaning: To be completely occupied with someone or on something.
example: Francis apologized for not being able to reply to my email. He explained that he'd been tied up all day long with meetings.

meaning: To be doing something, or planning to do something, that other people aren't expecting or that you perhaps shouldn't.
example: Do you think he's up to something? Lately, he's been acting in kind of sneaky way.

meaning: To do something in an exaggerated or extreme way
example: They bought enough soda yesterday to beat the band! Yes, I know we're having a picnic, but it seemed like they bought enough drinks for an entire army.

meaning: To speak to someone eagerly, especially in order to ask for a favor.
example: I thought Jake just wanted to chat, but it turned out he wanted to bend my ear; he spent the entire conversation trying to convince me to join his team.

meaning: To lose consciousness
example: It's very foolish and dangerous to drink so much alcohol that you black out.

meaning: To outwardly praise yourself for something.
example: I don't mean to blow my own horn, but I think I did really well with that task the other day

meaning: To fail something.
example: Cindy bombed her exam. She didn’t even get close to a passing grade.

meaning: To trap someone in a situation, or to put them in circumstances where their options are limited.
example: I felt boxed in by what they did. My options were so limited and I felt I had to do what they wanted.

meaning: To annoy someone.
example: They were really bugging me. It seemed like they were deliberately trying to be annoying.

meaning: To interrupt in a rude manner.
example: I don't mean to butt in, but I couldn't help but hear what you guys were talking about and I wanted to give my opinion.

meaning: To stop working for the day.
example: After we finished writing notes for the next meeting, we decided to call it a day and go home.

idiom: To call someone on the carpet
meaning: To confront someone with whom you're having a conflict.
example: My boss was tired of dealing with Henry's sloppy ways. He finally called him on the carpet yesterday.

idiom: To carry a torch for someone
meaning: To continue to have an infatuation with someone.
example: Henrietta claimed that she didn't like her ex-boyfriend anymore, but her friends knew that she still carried a torch for him.

meaning: To have been unprepared.
example: Daniel and Matthew came out flat-footed in their presentation. They stumbled over their lines and didn't do well.

meaning: To strongly defend oneself as a confrontation or debate begins.
example: We all assumed that Chris would win the debate, but Mandy really came out swinging.

meaning: To become the most dominant (or the only dominant) player in a specific area of the market.
example: That company really cornered the market with that product they released last year. No one else can compete!

meaning: To deliberately raise an alarm for no real reason.
example: He warned his nephew to never cry wolf. Raising an alarm over a fake situation now would result in people being less likely to believe him in the future if he encountered real trouble.

idiom: To do a number on something
meaning: To hurt or severely damage something.
example: All that time on the beach without sunscreen many years ago did a number on my skin. That's why I have so much sun damage now and I worry about skin cancer.

meaning: To forget something you specifically wanted to remember.
example: I was excited to tell them about it, but I ended up drawing a blank when I got the opportunity. I just couldn't remember what I wanted to say!

meaning: To drink a lot of alcohol on a regular basis.
example: They were worried about their friend because he drank like a fish every time they saw him

meaning: To visit unexpectedly.
example: Rose didn't like it when people just dropped by her house. She was embarrassed that it might be untidy.

meaning: To look for faults in someone or something.
example: She was so frustrated; it seemed like people at school were always finding fault with her hair and the way she dressed.

meaning: To check up on someone or something.
example: Nicole told me that she went to an interview a few days ago. She thinks she did really well on it and that she has a good chance of getting the job. She is wondering, though, whether or not she should follow up on it by sending a polite email.

idiom: To get bent out of shape
meaning: To become upset.
example: Don't get cry about it! There's really no reason to get so bent out of shape over a simple disagreement.

meaning: To contact.
example: It's strange that they haven't heard from Patricia this week. She promised that she'd get in touch with them.

meaning: To do away with something.
example: I think I'll get rid of all those old video tapes. After all, there's not much I can do with them now.

meaning: To get fired from your job.
example: I have terrible news. Darren got his walking papers today. He's going to have to look for a new job.

meaning: To decide to go along with something, usually as a result of some sort of pressure.
example: Their parents eventually gave in and said that they were allowed to go on a summer vacation with their friends.

meaning: To notify someone of something and to keep them up-to-date.
example: Beth sent an email to all of her friends, detailing her events for the big event. They really appreciated her giving them the heads-up.

idiom: To go down like a lead balloon
meaning: To be terribly received by an audience.
example: The new play did really badly. The audience hated it, and it went down like a lead balloon.

meaning: For every individual to pay for their own bill in a restaurant.
example: We decided to go Dutch at dinner. After all, it's so much easier when each person just pays for what they've eaten.

meaning: To gamble all of your resources.
example: Maggie decided to go for broke with her new endeavor. She has almost no money left. I hope it works out for her, but it seems pretty risky!

idiom: To go off the deep end
meaning: To get extremely upset and/or emotional.
example: Linda went off the deep end when she heard the bad news. I don't think I've ever seen anyone so upset.

meaning: To have something else that will happen in the near future that you didn't expect or think would happen.
example: Melinda thinks that her plan will work, but I say that she has another thing coming.

idiom: To have one's back to the wall
meaning: To feel trapped, with no real options to deal with the situation.
example: Jayden felt that his back was to the wall. He couldn't figure out how to get out of the situation; he didn't feel like he had any options to deal with it either

idiom: To hold out an olive branch
meaning: To offer a gesture of peace or to ask for forgiveness or a truce.
example: Judy and Adelaide had been friends for years but they didn't speak for a few months after they had an argument. Finally, Adelaide decided to hold out an olive branch.

meaning: To be confident and politely assertive with other people and in various situations.
example: Don't worry about my sister. She can hold her own in any situation. It's because she's so confident.

meaning: To closely watch and/or monitor.
example: Thomas is a very careful investor. He's always keeping an eye on the stock market.

meaning: To know someone when you look at them.
example: Dan couldn't remember her face, but he knew her on sight.

meaning: To live in a manner that requires more money than you can afford.
example: I told them that it's very unwise to live beyond one's means. It can lead you into a lot of debt.

meaning: To live with very little money.
example: They lived pretty much hand-to-mouth after they both lost their jobs.

meaning: To feel superior to someone else.
example: Juliana always looked down her nose at me and my friends. She was quite conceited and always thought she was above us.

idiom: To make a long story short
meaning: To tell someone something in a brief and simple way.
example: Lots of things happened yesterday. To make a long story short, we had a terrible time.

idiom: To make a mountain out of a molehill
meaning: To overreact and overstate a situation
example: You're blowing this out of proportion! Stop making a mountain out of a molehill. It's really not a very serious situation.

meaning: To worsen a problem
example: We were late for the party. And to make matters worse, we couldn’t find a parking space.

meaning: To cancel a plan or dismiss an idea, or to forbid something.
example: She decided to nix their plans to go away this winter. It was no longer possible.

meaning: To do better at something that one has done before.
example: Sophie was proud of herself last week. She outdid her previous achievements at the gym.

meaning: To be self-sufficient and think independently.
example: Josh has always been one to paddle his own canoe. He's very independent and does what he thinks is best, without seeking help from others

meaning: To pay money that is owed or that you need to pay for some other reason.
example: Come on and pony up! You know you still owe me that ten dollars I lent you a month ago.

meaning: To sometimes seem enthusiastic and other times seem the opposite.
example: He was worried that his girlfriend didn't like him anymore. She seemed to blow hot and cold. Sometimes she seemed to like him a lot, while other times she didn't.

meaning: To finally see something clearly and understand it.
example: I was so happy to hear that Victoria had seen the light about her boyfriend. He isn't very nice and she finally realizes that now.

meaning: It was a just consequence or punishment.
example: It serves him right! He did some really careless things; he deserves to suffer the consequences.

meaning: To restore peace to a situation or to resolve conflict.
example: Denise was good at helping her friends resolve arguments. She liked to help smooth things over.

meaning: To help defend someone.
example: Jill always stood up for me when others tried to bully me at school.

meaning: To start over again from the very beginning.
example: The birthday cake I made yesterday was a total disaster. I had to start over from scratch.

meaning: To be intentionally vague or to make insignificant statements in response to a question, specifically to avoid answering it
example: They tried to ask him questions but he was always stonewalling, finding ways to avoid giving real answers.

idiom: To take a load off someone's back
meaning: To relieve someone of a specific burden or a potential burden.
example: My friends really showed they cared when they took that load off my back. I would have had a terrible time without their help.

meaning: To relax and/or rest
example: Belle just finished a busy week at school. She's looking forward to taking it easy this weekend.

meaning: To assume that you would have had, or will have, something no matter what.
example: People accused Adrian of taking his friends for granted. He always just assumed that they'd be there for him, without giving them any consideration.

meaning: To do something in an extremely thorough way.
example: They went shopping for new summer wardrobes yesterday. They did it to the hilt, I have to say.

meaning: In a humorous spirit.
example: I couldn't figure out why she took what I said seriously. It was obvious that I meant it in a tongue-in-cheek way; I even laughed afterward.

meaning: Conceited and arrogant.
example: Don't you agree that Ben is too big for his boots? I think he is. He's very conceited.

idiom: Too many irons in the fire
meaning: To have an excessive number of activities taking up your time.
example: She was having a hard time concentrating on her work. After speaking to her, I realized that she has too many irons in the fire. Having so many things to worry about makes it hard to focus.

meaning: The person in charge.
example: Our boss is the top dog in this office.

meaning: Top quality.
example: The perfume he bought me for my birthday is top-notch. It’s a designer brand and extremely expensive. I love it.

meaning: An uncertain or otherwise precarious situation.
example: The situation was touch and go for a while. We had no way of knowing what would happen. Would everything be okay in the end?

meaning: To get in contact with someone.
example: Could you please touch base with me next week, to let me know how the project is progressing?

meaning: A history of doing something.
example: He has an excellent track record when it comes to academics. Have you seen his grades? They're great!

meaning: Ideas that come one after the other and are connected.
example: The alarm interrupted my train of thought. Now I can't remember what I had decided about the presentation.

meaning: Someone who has a chaotic and probably unsuccessful life.
example: She was upset when her old friend called her a train wreck.

meaning: To travel with very little luggage.
example: They decided to travel light for their trip to Europe, as they planned to do some backpacking.

meaning: To buy something for someone.
example: They treated the kids to ice cream yesterday.

meaning: To treat someone or something with extreme gentleness and respect.
example: They realized that, since their boss was so sensitive about his ideas, they would need to treat his pet project with kid gloves.

meaning: A difficult and unstable situation, and/or emotionally difficult times.
example: My friend helped me overcome troubled waters last year. I was scared because my situation at home seemed too unsettled and precarious.

meaning: Loyal and trustworthy.
example: Amy was true blue as a friend. I could always count on her to be there for me.

meaning: Very tired.
example: I had thought about going out tonight after work, but I'm just too tuckered out.

meaning: To refuse to acknowledge the reality of something.
example: We couldn't get Tommy to believe us about what had happened. He just wanted to turn a blind eye to it.

meaning: To search for something, probably an item one has lost, in a frantic way.
example: I couldn't find it, even though I turned my living room upside down while searching for it.

meaning: To change your life in order to make it (and probably your behavior) better.
example: Sarah said that she was going to turn over a new leaf in her life. She had made some bad decisions in the past, but she was determined to make better ones in the future.

meaning: To refrain from retaliating against something that offends you.
example: Olivia was always so patient and forgiving with everyone. If anyone did something that upset her, she would often turn the other cheek.

meaning: To switch places someone, putting them in the same sort of position you once occupied.
example: He turned the tables on the bully by standing up for himself; he showed everyone that the bully was really the one people should ignore.

meaning: To increase the amount of pressure on a person or situation.
example: The lawyer turned up the heat in his questioning of the witness.

meaning: To try to coerce someone into doing something.
example: Sally didn't want to go to the amusement park at first, but her friends twisted her arm.

meaning: Extremely similar and probably close.
example: The little girl and her best friend were very much alike. They were like two peas in a pod.

meaning: Being under some kind of suspicion.
example: Mike said that people thought he had done something wrong even though he hadn't. He found it hard to interact with them under that cloud.

meaning: To be under the control of someone else.
example: Jesse was under Alex's thumb. He looked up to Alex and wanted to be like him, but this ended up meaning that his friend could control him.

meaning: Illegally or secretly (especially with regard to being paid in such a way).
example: They received payments under the table. They didn't want to claim the money on their income taxes.

meaning: Not feeling well
example: Kristen wanted to come with us to the party, but she's feeling really under the weather. We think she might have flu.

meaning: To finish something just before it has to be completed.
example: Abby will probably get her paper done right under the wire. You know what she's like! She left it to the last minute.

meaning: A very long time.
example: I think they'll be arguing about this until the cows come home! I can't see them ever stopping.

meaning: Taking a course of action that will lead to a negative outcome.
example: I tried to convince him that he was going up a blind alley with his new plan, but he wouldn't believe me. I think things will turn out badly.

meaning: In a very difficult situation that might be impossible to extricate oneself from
example: I've been looking at the situation and, honestly, I think we're up a gum tree. I don't know how we can get ourselves out of this.

meaning: Available to obtain.
example: There is a lot of money up for grabs in the raffle. Let's hope we win!

meaning: To be very upset or angry about something specific.
example: The protestors were up in arms about the new law. They thought it was oppressive and wanted it to be changed.

meaning: Not yet decided.
example: Plans for our vacation this year are pretty much up in the air. There are so many options and we just can't decide among them.

idiom: Up the creek without a paddle
meaning: To be in a bad situation and not be able to find a way to solve it.
example: Maisie doesn't know what to do about the situation. She feels like she's up the creek without a paddle.

meaning: Meeting the standard of quality required.
example: My brother got a disappointing grade on his essay. The teacher said it just wasn't up to snuff.

meaning: To disturb the current situation or status quo in some way.
example: The employees didn't like the new changes their boss had made to their terms of employment, so they all decided to upset the apple cart and object.

meaning: Use your brain and think.
example: How could you not realize that you would need to do that? It's common sense. You really need to use your loaf!

meaning: To relax and not think about anything that stresses you out.
example: Let's not do much this afternoon. We can just veg out and enjoy some television.

meaning: To imagine yourself in someone else's position.
example: Janet was a very empathetic person. She always tried to imagine herself in the other person's shoes before making any sort of judgment or offering advice.

meaning: An easy and pleasant time.
example: The new job was certainly no walk in the park. It was quite challenging and difficult.

meaning: Happy or joyous.
example: Laura called me to say how happy she is about the prize she won. She seems to be walking on air.

meaning: Someone (usually a girl or woman) who is shy and doesn’t receive any attention, especially at a dance.
example: Marjorie was sad that she was always such a wallflower at dances. No one ever asked her to dance. Marie, on the other hand, was the opposite of a wallflower. She was very popular and everyone wanted to talk to her.

meaning: To completely stop caring about, and dealing with, someone.
example: I wanted to convince her that we could be friends. She has kept on being rude though, so I think I'll need to wash my hands of her.

meaning: If you refrain from wasting things, you won't have to go without.
example: Their grandmother was very good at saving and reusing things. Waste not, want not was her motto.

meaning: To keep alert and look around for something.
example: Watch out for bugs when you go for your hike next week.

meaning: Something that is now in the past and that isn't important anymore.
example: I can't understand why Melissa is still so worried about what happened. It really wasn't very important, and now it’s water under the bridge. It's in the past.

meaning: A bar (where alcohol is served).
example: My friends headed to a local watering hole for a few drinks.

meaning: Something that will be extremely prevalent in the future.
example: The company said that the new technology they invested in is sure to be the wave of the future.

meaning: We see things the same way and agree.
example: Many of her friends had disagreed with her on the issue, so she was glad to find that I agreed with her; we see eye to eye on other topics as well.

meaning: To have several different distinct roles.
example: Lindsay wears many different hats at her company. She works in at least three departments.

idiom: Wear your heart on your sleeve
meaning: To let your emotions be very obvious.
example: Chelsea is always very open about things. She really wears her heart on her sleeve; you can always tell what kind of mood she’s in.

meaning: To get out of doing something or taking responsibility for something.
example: Jane managed to weasel out of having to take her little brother to her appointment yesterday

meaning: Successfully come through some sort of difficulty.
example: There were lots of problems that we had to deal with and some people were afraid that they could not endure it. I was sure that we would weather the storm, though.

meaning: It's important to get a good start.
example: Megan was worried that she wouldn't do a good job on the project, but I thought she'd made a really good start. I reassured her and reminded her that well begun is half done

idiom: We'll cross that bridge when we come to it
meaning: We will deal with that problem when we have to.
example: Don't worry about that problem right now. We'll cross that bridge when we come to it.

meaning: Wealthy and well-dressed.
example: Chloe started working at an upscale boutique this week. She told me a bit about all of her well-heeled customers.

meaning: To do even more than is required.
example: The group went the extra mile with their class project. They did more than was required and ended up with an A+.

meaning: Inexperienced and probably young.
example: The new guy in the office is really young and wet behind the ears. He hardly has any experience in this field.

meaning: An individual who others feel ruins a fun or enjoyable experience.
example: Dan is such a wet blanket. He always tries to ruin the fun when we're having a party.

meaning: Have a drink of something when thirsty
example: Could you hold on a second? I need a few sips of water, just to wet my whistle.

meaning: What are you doing? (Often there is an implication the person in question is doing something they shouldn't; this can be playful in meaning.)
example: What are you up to? Are you eating candy even though lunch is in an hour?

meaning: Lots of things are causing difficulties or going wrong at the same time.
example: First the photocopier broke, and now her desk chair is wobbling. Everything seems to be going wrong this morning! When it rains, it pours!

meaning: Something that will never happen.
example: Are you serious? That's never going to happen. Maybe when pigs fly!

meaning: When it becomes necessary to act.
example: My brother might seem a bit flaky sometimes, but he's always there for me when push comes to shove.

meaning: When things aren't going well
example: Helen is always there for her friends when the chips are down. She never fails them in difficult situations.

idiom: Where the rubber meets the road
meaning: A critical moment or turning point in an endeavor.
example: Ben had been nervous about the basketball championships for months. Tomorrow was the day. It was time for the rubber to meet the road.

meaning: What were we talking about/doing?
example: Where we were in our conversation before we were interrupted?

meaning: A possession that is costly but fundamentally useless.
example: The family's new gazebo ended up being something of a white elephant. They spent a fortune on it and they never use it.

meaning: A slight lie or exaggeration, or a lie that doesn't do any harm.
example: Though Anna didn't tell the truth, she claimed it was only a white lie. What she said hadn’t hurt anyone.

meaning: To try to cover up something bad.
example: Everything seemed okay at first, but then we discovered that the real situation had been whitewashed.

meaning: No one asked you, so why are you offering an opinion?
example: Who asked you? I don't want your opinion on my jacket.

idiom: Who do you think you are?
meaning: Why do you think you're entitled to say/do that?
example: I can't believe you would say something so arrogant. Who do you think you are?

meaning: Everything, or all things, involved in something.
example: She took part in all kinds of extracurricular activities at college. Debate society, basketball, track and field. The whole ball of wax.

meaning: Untamed and wild.
example: Did you see Adam today? He was looking a bit wild and woolly, wasn't he?

meaning: Will occur.
example: The awards ceremony will take place two weeks from today.

meaning: To treat someone to an expensive meal.
example: David had a crush on Deanna. He wanted to take her out so that he could wine and dine her.

meaning: Doing something in the absence of preparation, planning, or some special knowledge.
example: It doesn’t seem like he's completely sure of what he's doing. He seems to be winging it while he tries to figure it out.

meaning: To feel a great sense of anticipation or expectation (could be positive or negative).
example: She waited for her exam results with bated breath.

meaning: With enthusiasm, usually when attending an event.
example: Anthony said that he was really excited about the upcoming festival and that he'd be there with bells on!

meaning: To do something extremely well.
example: Adam passed the exam with flying colors! He got an A+.

meaning: Someone who has the appearance of being good but who actually has negative or bad intentions.
example: They thought that he would be a good business partner, but he turned out to be a wolf in sheep's clothing

meaning: To work on something that you probably won't get done in time.
example: We were working against the clock to get the project done on time

meaning: Competent at what one does.
example: It took a while for the boss to decide whether or not his new employee was worth his salt.

meaning: Would never want to do something, probably because it would cause embarrassment.
