example: Maria hated the new blue sweater that her parents had bought her. She thought it looked terrible on her and told her friends that she wouldn't be caught dead in it.

meaning: Very gentle and unable, or unlikely, to ever hurt anyone or anything.
example: Don’t worry about her. She wouldn't hurt a fly; she’s very gentle.

idiom: Wouldn't touch it with a ten-foot pole
meaning: Would never even think about coming anywhere close to it or becoming involved with it.
example: Frank and Ashley agreed about the open position at the company down the road. They wouldn't touch it with a ten-foot pool. Neither would be applying.

meaning: To understand a complex subject.
example: I didn't understand how to solve the math problem. I just couldn't seem to wrap my head around it.

meaning: To have found what one was looking for.
example: Here it is! The notebook I was looking for. X marks the spot!

meaning: That's right, I will, or I agree.
example: You bet! I'd love to come with you tomorrow.

meaning: I think it's definitely true.
example: You can bet your boots that it's true! I'm absolutely sure of it.

idiom: You can bet your bottom dollar
meaning: You can be certain.
example: You can bet your bottom dollar that Ethan's new business will do well. He's an incredibly hard worker and there is demand in the area for his services.

idiom: You can lead a horse to water, but you can't make him drink
meaning: You cannot compel another person to make the right decision.
example: I tried to convince Brooke that she would do better in the other course, but she wouldn't listen. It's true, you know. You can lead a horse to water, but you can't make him drink.

meaning: I agree or that is true.
example: You can say that again! I agree that the weather was terrible.

idiom: You can't have your cake and eat it too
meaning: It's impossible to have everything.
example: Margaret was frustrated that she couldn't afford to buy both tops at once, but she realized that you can't have your cake and eat it too.

idiom: You can't judge a book by its cover
meaning: You shouldn't try to judge someone or something just by how it looks.
example: He thought that his teacher looked like she might be mean, but people told him that he shouldn't judge a book by its cover

idiom: You can't make an omelet without breaking some eggs
meaning: There are always costs involved when accomplishing something.
example: Some people were upset about the costs of the endeavor. We just had to remind them that you can't make an omelet without breaking some eggs.

idiom: You can't squeeze blood out of a turnip
meaning: You cannot get something out of nothing.
example: Matt was really frustrated at how people were demanding that he pay the money he owed. He told them that he didn't have the funds, and that you can't squeeze blood out of a turnip.

idiom: You can't take it with you
meaning: No matter how much money or how many material possessions you have, you can't take them with you when you die.
example: The couple decided to go on a world cruise. It was very expensive, but they didn’t mind. After all, you can't take it with you.

idiom: You can't teach an old dog new tricks
meaning: It's harder for an older person to learn new information.
example: He was nervous about going back to school because of people telling him that you can't teach an old dog new tricks. He did really well, though!

idiom: You get what you pay for
meaning: If you buy something very cheap, you cannot complain about it being low quality.
example: I know you're frustrated about the stitches coming loose on your new top, but you get what you pay for. It was very cheap.

idiom: You'll catch more flies with honey than with vinegar
meaning: Being nice will make it easier to get what you want.
example: Some people wonder why I'm always so nice to Jack, when he’s so difficult and uncooperative. But I always say that you'll catch more flies with honey than with vinegar.

idiom: Your guess is as good as mine
meaning: I don't have the information needed to know the answer.
example: Did you ask what the weather will be like tomorrow? Your guess is as good as mine.

meaning: That's obviously true.
example: You're telling me! There’s no way that huge diamond is real.

meaning: You have convinced me.
example: Okay, I'll go to the concert with you. You've sold me on it. It sounds like it will be a lot of fun.

meaning: Refusal to tolerate something at all.
example: The school has a zero tolerance policy when it comes to any sort of violence.

meaning: Be quiet.
example: Our teacher lost his patience. He told one of the loudest students to zip it.
